Done by Mr. John Moore, Apothecary, at the Pestle and Mortar, in Abchurch-Lane, near umbard-street.

DIV1.HEAD: THE Epistle Dedicatory. TO THE Right Reverend Father in GOD, Dr. John Moore, Lord Bishop of ELY.
DIV1.P:
AN indispensible Necessity, obliging me to vindicate my Reputation in the Knowledge and Practise of Physick, against the Malicious Calumnies and De∣tractions of my Enemies; who
are only those of my own Pro∣fession, and such as are unwarily prejudic'd by their False and Scandalous Insinuations; I hope I shall not be charg'd either with Vanity or Rashness in Publishing these brief Essays; which are de∣sign'd for no other end, but that by reading this little Mannual, those that are Strangers to my Person, may be convinc'd, that in Studying Physick, I have fol∣lowed such Learned Guides and Patterns, by whose Directions and Examples, and my own Expe∣rience, joined with a tolerable Capacity, and an indefatigable In∣dustry and Diligence, that I am legally qualified for the Exercise of the Art I profess, maugre the inveterate Malice of all Op∣posers.

My Lord, My Life and Con∣versation, I bless God, being unattackable, even by Envy it
self, and so being no Reproach to the Name I have the Ho∣nour to bear: And your Lord∣ship being Celebrated for your Exemplary Piety, Charity, and profound Knowledge in Physick, as well as in all other Learned and useful Arts and Sciences, and consequently a Proper and Sufficient Judge, of the Contents of the following Treatise.

I have humbly presum'd to Dedicate it to your good Lord∣ship, in great Sincerity, but in very plain Language; for if Nature had been more kind and liberal to me in Eloquent and Rhetorical Expressions, I durst not have used them to your Lord∣ship, who takes more Delight in doing good to others, than in read∣ing deserved Panegyricks on your self.

And therefore if your Lord∣ship is pleas'd to Pardon or Excuse my Confidence in this Address, and favourably accept the tender of this diminutive Tract, I shall esteem that great Condescention, as an Eternal Obligation and Honour, con∣ferr'd upon,

CLOSER.SIGNED: My good Lord, Your Lordships Most Devoted Humble Servant John Moore.

DIV1.HEAD: A PRACTICAL DISCOURSE, Shewing the Origine, Seat, Symptoms, Cause, &c.
DIV1.P:
The Intro∣duction in defence of the Au∣thor.IF ever any Person upon the Face of the Universe, that Dedicated his whole Life to the doing good, and rendring himself Bene∣ficial to Mankind, has reason to complain of the Ill and Barbarous usage he has en∣countred, from Men of his own Profession, and others of a Superior Station, that pre∣tend Authority to License or Suppress, all Practioners in the Noble and Useful Arts of Pharmacy, and Administring Physick, I am the Man; for ever since I took my leave of the Old and Useless way of giving Phy∣sick, as too many others do, Blindfold, by Traditional Prescriptions, and made it my whole
Study and Business to keep up an entire Correspondence and Agreement between Art and Nature, Theory and Practice; and made exact and particular Observations in the difference of Diseases, the variety of Symptoms, casual Accidents, and the diversity of Con∣stitutions in Humane Bodies; and have followed the dictates of a well-grounded Experi∣ence, in finding out the Essence of Diseases, and the Efficacy of Proper Medicines to Cure them. The whole Tribe of common Practioners, and some graduated Professors of Physick, that live lazing upon the little Knowledge that comes by Tradition, and by stuffing their Bills, and Patients with Nauseous Re∣petitions, of unexperienc'd and consequently ineffectual Medicines; have both unsuffer∣ably calumniated, traduced and slander'd me, with many ridiculous Stories and un∣just Censures, as well as loaded me with such hard and reproachful Names, as none but the bountiful bestowers of them can deserve; so that I am forc'd, to prevent others from being prejudiced by false Reports and mali∣cious Insinuations, to take this way of vin∣dicating my Reputation, against the Insults of Envious Men, who are as utter Stran∣gers to my Person and Abilities, as them∣selves are from the common Principles of Modesty, Civility and good Manners.

I could with great facility recriminate upon my Enemies, but I never thought a Billings-Gate Dialect any Ornament, or an advantageous Character to a Sober Chri∣ftian, which is seldom used, but by a buisy sort of Tatling Animals, who are out of Humour with every Body, because their own ill nature will not suffer 'em to be
pleas'd with themselves. Let Maevius and Bavius then admire one another, and rail at all the World besides; I shall for the future be unconcern'd at those who are as full of unjust Reproaches, as they are void of good Breeding. I wish to be hated by self-interested Slanderers and their Abettors, for the same reason for which I desire to be belov'd by all Ingenious, well meaning ho∣nest Men, under all Denominations; as for the rest, I shall say with the Poet

L.HI: Ʋrg'd by the Base, I'm unconcern'd the while,
At least regard it with a scornful Smile;
'Twere mean to think of Vengeance on the Vile.

DIV1.P: However, since I know not how far their Hatred, inveterate and implacable Malice may extend to my prejudice, among those that know not my veritable Character, I shall here employ a few Lines to answer all the Objections they have raised, and industri∣ously scatter'd to blast my Reputation in the Practice of Physick, which I have followed with great Success for many Years, and which the worst of my Enemies cannot de∣ny, without assurance enough to affirm, that the Sun is not risen, when to their shame, it shines in their Faces from its Illustrious Meridian.

Objections against the Author.The first Quarter in which my professed Enemies attack me, is, That I am but an Apothecary: 'Tis true, I lay claim to no greater Title, and yet cannot forbear say∣ing, That that Objection is Ridiculous; since being an Apothecary, well versd in Phar∣macy, in the Knowledge of Drugs, and the Composition of Medicines, is, the most cer∣tain
and regular step towards the making of a good Physician: As has been proved by many Examples in London and other Places, where Men that servd their Times to Apothecaries, and kept Shop many Years, have afterwards took their Degree of Doctor in one of our own Universities, and pra∣ctised with as great Applause, and it may be with more Success, than the rest of their only Graduated Brethren. Nor is this method unobserved in other Learned Employments; for many Wise Men say, That the way to make an able Counsellor, is, First to educate him as a Clerk to an At∣torney. Having thus blown off this igno∣rant and contemptible Objection, I proceed to the Second; which is, That I never had, an Ʋniversity Education, but am a mere Ignoramus, as they are pleas'd to Phrase it; But how will they prove their latter Allegation? Did they ever Examine into my Learning and Ability? Do they know my Incapa∣city to perform what I undertake? If they did, without doubt I should long since have heard of it in louder Terms, than by Private Whispers, Malicious Insinuations and Secret Calumnies and Aspersions; but such is their Hatred, that what they dare not aver to my Face, or attempt to prove by Argument, they liberally supply by false Reports, and forged Clandestine Stories of my Insufficiency, against a Thousand credible Certificates and Reputable Testimonies to the contrary; and these I think sufficient to stop the Mouths of Detraction and Envy, in the Opinion of all good People; and for o∣thers, that are mislead by my Numerous Ad∣versaries into uncharitable Censures of me;
let them but consider, that my Enemies treat me on the score of Demetrius, for my safe and short way of Practice, and a great number of Patients diminishing their Profit, they will not wonder that I am con∣demn'd in an Arbitrary Court, where Ma∣lice is the Prosecuter, Interest sits as Judge, and sordid Ignorance is Fore-Man of the Jury. I confess, I have not had the Advantage of an Academick Education, but am a sincere lover of Learning, and desirous of Know∣ledge, and tho' I cannot boast of posses∣sing much, yet I can astute all Censorious Pedants, that by conversing with Learned Men, and a well chosen Library, I take as much pains to encrease my Knowledge, as some of them do by insignificant Diversions, and notorious Debaucheries, to lose what they gain'd, if ever they gain'd any thing but Words at the Ʋniversity. Besides, this cavil is wholly Impertinent, since its well known, beyond a possibility of Contradi∣ction, that I am Master of good Specificks, and establish'd experimented Medicines, of my own Preparing, which Prescribing? Physici∣ans cannot pretend to, tho' of the greatest Consequence to Mankind, and whose effi∣cacious Vertues I am sure of, and can rely upon, in the most difficult plunging Cases in respect of Safety, and generally with Suc∣cess; and all this confirmed by numerous Testimonies of Cured Patients, which I am of Opinion, is all that ought t be required of a good Physician; and yet for want of the empty Title of Doctor, and a Coach and Equipage, I must, it seems, be called Quack and Emperick, by chose Doni of the Pro∣fession, who have not much more Skill in
the true Practice of Physick, which I take to be the Cure of Diseases, than what they collect from the old exploded Methodus Medendi, which when the World grows Wiser, will vanish into its original nothing, and give place to solid, certain and veri∣table Experience in the Cure of Diseases.

And that I may contribute to this great End, of advancing useful Knowledge in Phy∣sick, and that my Enemies may not think I am reduced to a perpetual silence in my own just Defence, by their vain Threatnings and injurious Misrepresentations of my Person and Capacity for the Practice of Physick, I have taken up a resolution to Print se∣veral Discourses upon those Diseases, that God has bless'd me with the Knowledge of, and given me wonderful success in their Cures, that have frequently baffled the Endeavours of many Eminent Professors: And shall be∣gin with a Treatise upon the CHOLICK.

Now in discoursing this Subject, to avoid all unnecessary and over Nice and Curious Distinction, and Definitions, that rather puzzle Men's Intellects, than benefit their Understandings, I shall under the general Name, vulgarly called Cholick, treat of it as an Accidental and Particular Distemper, arising from an evident Cause alone, and without a previous disposition in any Per∣son indifferently; for so, alterations in the Sex Nonaturalia often raise great commotions in the Viscera of the Belly with extremity of Pain: After that, I shall consider this Disease in its Procartick or pre-existent Cause, as co-operating with others that are sub∣sequent, which will necessarily lead me to
particular Discourses upon the various kinds, and the several Species of this Distemper under the denominations of the Cholick in the Stomach; the Hysterick Cholick, the Scor∣butick Cholick; the Iliack Passion, the Caeliack Cholick, a Diarrhea, a Lientary, a Dysentry, &c. All which Distempers I shall treat particularly, and to avoid Confusion and over burthening the Memory, under every Head I shall shew the Origine Seminium or Minera of each Disease; what part of the Body is primarily affected; then proceed to the Symptoms and Method of Cure, and con∣clude with some Observations and Exam∣ples, wherein my own Medicines have been wonderfully successful; which I always keep ready prepared by me, to dispose of, to all that think fit to come or send for them.

The Essence or Nature of the Cho∣lick.The Cholick called in Greek , in Latin Collica Passio, because by some Physitians, 'tis supposed, tho' falsly, to have its seat wholly in some part or other of the Se∣cond of the great Guts, called Colon; is a Vellication or severe Griping, Twitching, Gnawing Pain in certain Parts of the Ab∣domen, which commonly produce Vomit∣ings, Cramps and Contractions, almost of all the Viscera of the Belly: Sometimes the Navel and its Neighbouring Parts are drawn inward, accompanied with Pains as if they were boared with a Gimlet: Sometimes they swell, being blown up with the excess of Wind: The Intestines by an inverted Motion of the Fibres are often drawn up∣wards, insomuch that the Belly being ex∣treamly bound, discharges little or nothing at all; nay, tho' it be frequently provoked to do it by Glysters and Suppositories, yet
it does not easily throw out its Con∣tents.

That the Stomach is likewise convulsed with the Duodenum and Gall Bladder, mani∣festly appears from the plentiful vomiting of Yellow or Green Choler. Sometimes the Ʋreters and the Bladder which contains the Urine, are so contracted, that during the whole Fit, the Urine is either stopt, or voided more sparingly: Besides, the Head is grieved with Vertiginous effects, either preceding or following the invasion of this Disease, and if the Cholick encreases and becomes Inveterate, it often causes Pain in the outward Members and terminates in a Palsey.

Its direful Effects.Nay, the Sick commonly endures all kinds of Pains; one while burning with intole∣rable Heat, another time chill'd with extream Cold; sometimes it seems to be fix'd and as it were piercing the Loins, or ther whiles pricking with wandring repeated Thrusts; anon distending or beating the Loins, or only pressing them with the sense of weight, or burning, corroding, rending Pain; or is troubled either with a continual or interrupted Pulsation, and afterward returning again, or wonder∣fully writhing and contorting any other way, scarce to be expressed by the Patient, or explain'd by the Physician.

Now tho' all the differences occurring in this Distemper with its Original are very difficult to be assign'd, numbred, or re∣duced into a certain Order, and much more to make an exact Examination of all the Symptoms and Causes, and thence to give a sollid judgment of every one; yet I shall attempt it, by exhibiting them from the
best Authorities, and leave the choice to your own Election, as they are most agree∣able to your Reason and Experience, which is the Mistress both of the Learned and Unskilful.

The Origin of the Cho∣lick.Some are of Opinion that the Origine of this Disease, proceeds from the effervescency of vicious Blood; others from an Obstruction of the Capillary Veins of the Stomach and Guts, by which the Blood is forced to stand still in the Vessels, till at length after a great Distention the Vessels burst and the Blood is effussed, which breeds a sensible Inflamation and violent Pulsation about the Part affected. Others say it arises from an over viscous Phlegm mix'd with Choler, of∣fensive both in its Saltish Acrimony and Vo∣latile Oiliness, by which the Viscous Phlegm is rarified into Wind, and if the Excrements are contain'd beyond their due time, they harden and stick to the Gut, by which the natural Ferment is viciated, and the Windy Gusts are more rarified, and being shut up in the Cavity of the Gut Colon it causes a violent distension and contraction of it.

Some again impute it the disorders and Convulsions of the Nerves running from the Mesenterick Plexus, which vicious hu∣mours as aforesaid, lodg'd in the Intestines, and those by a Forreign irritation of their Nerves, equally attended by the successive returns of Cold, and Heat, cause tearing, wringing and ccting Pains.

Others ascribe s Original to the a∣bounding Acidity and Acrimony of the Pancreatick juice, occasion'd by over sharp Food; eating raw Fruits, by Summer Air too Hot, by Winter Air too Cold, or at least
too Sharp; by Fear, Sorrow, extream Grief or Solicitude of Mind; by continued Watchings which consume the Animal Spirits, and by consequence encreasing the Acrimony of any Humours, produce Hypocondriack suffocations, and also Pains, severely racking and con∣torting the Guts. Now the Reasons why I cannot agree with many Physicians, that Cholick Pains proceed from the sharp and irritative contents of the Colon, is, because those Medicines which loosen the Belly, and copioussly expel Featus's and the Faeces, would undoubtedly give most certain Re∣lief, the contrary of which too often hap∣pens, viz. That after frequent or violent Purging, that Disease becomes worse. Nor can I agree with the Notion, that Cholick Pains proceed only from the Pancreatick juice mix'd with Choler, because it's impossible, according to Sylvius de la Boe that the Juice of the Pancreas in any manner or degree sowre, should mix with Choler, abounding with a bitter and volatile Salt. Therefore,

I firmly adhere to the Opinion of the Learned Dr. Willis, who with great reason, places the Origine of this Disease among the effects of the Brain and the Genus Nervosum, alledging, that certain Recrements of the Nervous Humour, falling from the Brain by the Nerves, and passing thence into the Me∣sentry and other Foldings of the Abdomen, are there amass'd and heaped together, which if they are so gross, thick and viscous, that they cannot be received and sent away by the Lymphaducts, or distill'd out into the Cavities of the Intestines, by the small Branches of the Vessels, then Stagnating and being heaped together by degrees into those
Parts, they arise at length to an irritative plenitude: And afterward that Matter becoming more degenerate, and more offen∣sive by Stagnation, and growing turged on some occasion; or of its own accord or else fermenting with the Salino-fix'd Humour, sent thither from the Blood, will torture the Patient with very troublesome and painful Corrugations in the Branches of the Nerves and Nervous Fibres, with which the Mesen∣tery is innumerably furnish'd: Which ef∣fects of them, do seldom or never cease till the fermenting Matter is either discuss'd, or express'd into the Cavities of the Intestines, or at length by Care and the Application of proper Medicines, they are utterly sub∣dued.

Having thus briefly shew'd you the Na∣ture of the Cholick in the direful effects it produces, together with its Origination, I shall, according to promise, proceed to the Place that is primarily affected in Human Bodies.

The seat of the CholickSenertus and Riverius, place it in the up∣per Orifice of the Stomach, which is of ex∣quisite Sense, by reason of the intermixture of Nerves, with which it is stored from the vaga sexta, from whence Branches being communicated to the Heart that noble Part is also affected by Consent, and disperses the Pain into almost every part Internal and external.

Dr. Blankard, Professor of Physick, at Middleburgh, in Zealand, says, The Cholick is a vehement Pain, proceeding from an ill disposition of the Animal Spirits, seated in the Abdomen, but begins in the Nervous Plexus's or Foldings of the Mesentery, and is
by some Men falsly imputed to have its residence in the Gut Colon.

Michael Etmuller, late Professor of Physick in the University of Leiptsick, says, Cholick Pains and Gripings in the great Guts, are chiefly felt in the Colon, especially in that part of it towards the circumference of the Belly, upon the Left-side, where 'tis strait∣ned and incurvated, and consequently more liable to the blast and shocks of Wind, and more apt to stop the Circulation of the Excrements, and cause their Swelling up in∣to a hard or soft Tumor. This Pain and Tumor is frequently imputed to the Spleen, but erroneously; for the Colon, says he, is its usual and proper Seat; and sometimes it veers about to the Right-side of the Belly, upon the outermost Circumference, where the same Colon pursues its Course.

Sometimes these Pains reach only the Small Guts, and then their Station is about the Navel and Centre of the Belly, and are much more violent than those in the Great Guts; if they range not beyond the Duodenum, or the beginning of the Jejunum, they are felt in the Loins, and are often mi∣staken for Nephritick Pains, or those caused by the Convulsion of the Mesenterick Nerves, or Tumors, or Ulcers in the Pancreas. I dare not say any of these Opinions are He∣terodox, because sometime or other Pains do possess all the Parts above mention'd.

However, for very good Reasons grounded upon many Experiments in Anatomy, I ad∣here chiefly to Doctor Willis, who says, The Part in Human Bodies primarily affected in the Cholick, is the Mesentery, and its Ner∣vous Foldings under the Navel, which causes
cruel Pain, as if a Stake was stuck there, or a Piercer were making a Hole: Besides, round about, almost in the whole Abdomen, by reason of the Intestines being variously drawn forward and backward, at the same time in different Places, wandring Pains shoot this way and that way; and the mo∣tion of the Fibres being discomposed or in∣verted, as well in those Parts as in the pri∣mary Vessels, the Belly is in a manner al∣ways bound, and there follows sometimes a supperssion of Urine, or very little is made. Besides, the Duodenum the Gall Bladder with its Channels and the bottom of the Stomach being affected with a Cramp, and their Fibres being drawn upward, a frequent Vomiting with a copious casting up Matter of Yellow or Greenish colour often happens during the Fit.

In a Fit of the Cholick, also besides Pains of the Belly, there are likewise violent Pains of the Loins, raging in the 1ower parts of the Back, which certainly cannot pro∣ceed from the irritation of any Intestine; but its easy to conceive they may arise from a Morbific Cause lodg'd in the Mesentery: For inasmuch as several considerable Nerves of the Loins enter into the great Nervous fold∣ing of the Mesentery; so from hence, not on∣ly painful Convulsions are conveyed by con∣sent from one Part to another; but its also probable, that certain Recrements of the Back likewise, and of the Loins, are derived into the Mesentery by this Passage, and that in some sort, for this reason, Scorbutical Persons are so very obnoxious to Gripes of the Belly, and Looseness that attends it, which confirms me in the Opinion that the Nervous Flexus
of the Mesentery, is the first Part affected with the Cholick, and that its seat is not in the Cavities or Tnicles of the Intestines, nor the Morbifick Matter conveyed by the Arteries, but by Nerves.

Diagno∣stick Sym∣ptoms.Diagnostick Signs of the Cholick, are, very sharp Pains, sometimes moveable and other whiles fix'd to a certain place; some∣times the Pain is in the region of the Stomach or in the Reins, sometimes above and some∣times below the Navel, so that by the com∣parison of other Signs, you must distinguish between the Cholick and Pains of the Stone or Spleen, which are frequently mistaken one for the other, even by Physicians them∣selves.

Progno∣stick Sym∣ptoms of the Cholick.Prognosticks of the Cholick, are vulgarly enough known, that is to say, an Accidental Cholick rising from an evident cause alone, is commonly safe, and admits of an easy Cure; but an habitual one, is not eradicated but with great Difficulty, as to its dispo∣sition, so that the Fits may return no more; for sometimes the Fits themselves, notwith∣standing the Application of Medicines, are very obstinate and continue many Days, nay, Weeks and Months, and sometimes are never cured but by Death. Thus much for signs; But since I have branch'd out this Disease into several Parts, I shall take leave, once for all, to shew, how you may distin∣guish one Disease from another by the Urine.

Signs by the Urine.If the Urine is Watery, 'tis a Nephritick Cholick, if highly tinctur'd towards the middle, and colour'd on the Surface, and the Anus is obstinately bound; 'tis a Scor∣butick Cholick; if Respiration is difficult and
the Breast afflicted, 'tis a Hysterick Cholick; if the Convulsion of the Intestines is accom∣panied with Pain extending to the Pubes and Haunch-Bone, the Womb is disorder'd; if the Urine is clear and of a reddish Yellow, 'tis a Cholerick Cholick, if the Pain is tearing and the Urine Milky and Pale, impregnated with a large Sediment, the Mesenterick Nerves are affected.

Causes of the com∣mon Cho∣lick.The Antecedent Causes of the Common Cho∣lick, which I only treat of under this Head, are, the Disorder and Convulsions of the Nerves running from the great Mesenterick Plexus, which cause tearing, wringing and contracting Pains: Sometimes occasion'd by Nephritick Pains and Child-Birth, when the Mesenterick folding, being irritated, by its concourse with the Nerves of the Kidneys and the Womb,Antece∣dent Cau-Causes. pulls and contracts both the Stomach and Guts which it supplies with Nerves. At other times they are re∣tainers to some fix'd, permanent, habitual Cause, which tho' it lye hid for some time, has always an Ascendant in the Body. These are either Hypochondriack, Hysterick or Scor∣butick, as I shall further shew, when I treat particularly of those Diseases a part, and are owing to the Convulsion of the Mesen∣terick Plexus, to which the Intestines are an∣nex'd, being gall'd with a peccant Acid.

Procatar∣tick Causes.The Procatartick, or Pre-existent Cause of this Disease which co-operates with others that are subsequent, are two fold; First, That many Recrements or superfluous things are heaped together in the Nervous Li∣quor; and Secondly, That they being ad∣mitted chiefly into the Nerves of the Viscera of the Belly, and so conveyed into the Me∣sentery,
there create the Morbid Minera's of this Distemper; for the former of these generally happening by the Distemper of the Brain, by admitting Heterogeneous Particles with the Nervous Juice into its custody, the whole Animal Oeconomy is so disturb'd, that it cannot evacuate the common super∣fluities by its ordinary Conveyance; and this causes the incongruous Matter that can∣not be sent from the Brain, to force its pas∣sage into the Nerves of the Par vagum, which are open and ready to receive it. Se∣condly, That this superfluous Matter run∣ning in this manner into the Par vagum of the Nerves, is deposed in the Mesentery, or other foldings within the Abdomen, and necessarily makes the Morbid seat in the Mesentery.

Evident Causes.The evident Causes of the Cholick are also of two sorts; First, Such as being injurious to the Brain and Genus Nervosum, cause the Morbifick Matter to super abound: Or, Secondly by agitating the Blood and Hu∣mors, stir up the conglobated Mass to Pain, causing more fervent and sudden efferve∣scencies. And here some will imagine I should proceed to discourse the many and diversi∣fied occasions, by which the Pains of the Cholick are caus'd in Persons pre-disposed to them; but that would be nauseating the Reader with Cramben biscoctum, having suf∣ficiently done it already, in the Paragraph enttuled the direful effects of the Cholick, Page the 14th.

Cure of the Chlick.And now according to the Method I have prescribed to my self, I am brought to treat of what ought to be the Main and Principal design of every Practitioner in Physick in
all Diseases, viz. The Cure of the Disease. To compass which great end, Three primary In∣dications are suggested. First, To appease the Pains in the Fit. Secondly, To take a∣way the Cause of the Disease that the Fits may no more, or not so frequently return. Thirdly, To re-invigorate the Patient's Strength, and fortify his Constitution, in order to the Comfortable enjoyment of Life.

To appease the torturing Pains in the Paroxism, Lenifying and Emollient Glysters only, ought to be frequently injected into the Body, that the Corrugations of the Fi∣bres may be mitigated, and the raging of the Spirits appeased. To this end, Warm Milk with Sugar, or rather Molossus, or Syrup of Violets: Also Emollient Decoctions of March-Mallows, Herb Mercury, and the Flowers of Melilot with Oil of Almonds; also a strong Decoction of a Sheep's-Head with the Wool on it, or Calves-Feet, are proper to be used: Sometimes a Glyster of mear Oil of Olives or of Linseeds, have given Ease, when others have failed. But if this sort of Glysters are ineffectual and do not come away, or answer their end stronger must be used, to force the Humours from the little Mouths of the Arteries. For this purpose et Carminative or bitter Decoctions be prepred, in which dissolve Electuary Dia∣phoenic, Diacatholicon, or e Baccis Lauri, or Species Hierae, to which Liquors its customary to add, Two or Three Ounces of the infusion of Crocus Mettalorum: Or to a Pound of an Emollient Decoction, add of Venice Turpentine dissolv'd with the Yolk of an Egg, one Ounce; or take the Ʋrine of a Healthy Man, Venice Turpentine dissolv'd, one Ounce and half, and
with one Ounce of Molossus mix'd with the rest, make a Glyster. The Balsamick Particles of the Turpentine diffused every where, are de∣sign'd to remove the Morbifick or Stagnating Matter, or encline that which is Acetous, or otherwise degenerate, to a better Tem∣perament.

If the Intestines are much contracted by vicious Matter lodg'd within them, Purgations ought to be prohibited, for fear they promoe the Contraction, and lock up the Excrements closer. If this Case happens in your Practice, Whey, or an Ounce of the Oil of Almonds, with Canary Wind and Sperma Caeti, are more effectual than the strongest Catharticks, If the Cholick is attended with a Tenacious viscid Humour, and a heavy boring Pain, Purgatives mix'd with attenuating Specificks are allowable; tho' I have observ'd, 'tis bet∣ter to do so after the Fit has made some progress, and the Symptoms are a little mit∣tigated, than just in the beginning, especially if the Pain is violent; but take notice, that if the Guts are inflamed, all Laxatives of what∣soever ind are extreamly pernicious; for a fierc nd very violent Cholick, if it pro∣ceed from an Inflamation or Abscess of some of the Intestines, generally ushers in a Mor∣tal Iliack Passion.

External Applica∣tions.As for External Applications against Cho∣licks, let the Belly and Navel be well fo∣mented with Liniments, of express'd Oils, mix'd with those that are Distill'd. Galbanum melted and mix'd with the Distill'd Oils of Spike and Amber. Plaifters made of Tachamahas, Balsam of Peru, or that of Bay-Berries, with that of Tobacco; Cataplasms of Horse-Dung, with Oil of Rue; and quilted Bags of Mil∣let-seeds,
or of Anodyn and Aromatic Ingre∣tlients; are like wise apply'd to the Belly with good success. But if the Gripes of the Belly do not remit by the use of these things, you must have recourse to Hypnoticks, which being given in a sitting Dose, often gives Relief. And in continued Cholicks notwith∣standing some Men, Whose Ignorance, is as considerable as their Insolence, loudly cla∣mour against the use of Mercurial Medi∣cines, yet the raising a gentle Salivation when the Morbifick Matter is plentifully gather'd together in the Nervous Plexus's, and other places about the Abdomen, and there sticking fast, so as not to be moved by other Medicines, Calomel may be given to the Relief of the Patient, and without Reproach to the Physician.

The Pre∣servative Indication.To refresh the Strength and falling Spi∣rits of the Sick, and to order yet a greater Apparatus against the Disease, give Liquid Laudanum tartariz'd, at Bed-time, in a Spoon∣ful of the Water of Camomil Flowers, drinking after it, of the same six Spoonfuls, and let it be repeated every other, or every third Night. And whilst you are using these Me∣dicines for appeasing Pains, let Purging Re∣medies have their due Turns, to destroy the Seminium of the Disease, and to prevent its return, Vomiting and Purging, and in a Hot Temperament Phebotomy ought to be used: And instead of Baths and Sudorificks, Diure∣icks may be more advantageously given.
And where the Cholick is of long continu∣ance and obstinate, Spaw-Water coming from Iron-Mines, are often used with good Success:

The Vital Indication.Next, The Vital Indication ought to be join'd with the Curatory, and to be now and then interchangeably used with it: To that end, let Remedies be used which support the Patient's Strength, refresh his pirits and procure certain times of Truce against the Fits of the Disease. Let the Diseased be dusy supplied with Cordials, Paregoricks and Hypnoticks, which in the Cholick are so abso∣lutely necessary, that the Patient cannot live without them, nor the Physician justif him∣self, before the Tribunal of his own Con∣science. In Constitutions that are not Hot, Spirits of Heart-Horn, of Soot, of Sal-Armoni∣ack succinated, also Tincture of Antimony, or o Coral, are all very commendable. And when the Sick is deliver'd from his Pains, and has recover'd a competency of Strength; to com∣pleat his Cure, I recommend travelling long Journies on Horseback, or in a Coach, for such excitations of the Parts, will strengthen the Bowels, shake off the Relicks of the Dis∣ease, and make Life Pleasant and Comfort∣able, till the devouring Teeth of Time shall destroy that as well as every thing else.

The Au∣thor's own Remedies.Having thus briefly given you the Nature, Origine, Seat, Symptoms, Cause and Cure of this Excrusiating Disease call'd the Cholick, with the choicest Remedies used by the most celebrated Physicians of former Ages, and the present Time; I shall now, according to Promise, say something of my own Me∣dicines, that the bountiful Giver of all good things has bless d me with the Knowledge of, and which I can depend upon, from uncon∣tradicted Experience in many Years Practice, for the certain Cure of this Disease, in all Cureable Cases, and for giving Ease in the most
Dangerous, whose Obstinacy and Inveteracy will not admit, of a Perfect Cure: Which Remedies are of three, sorts, a Chimical Elixir, an Anticholical Cordial Water, Pills, and an Electuary; all safe and Salubrious in their Nature, and effectual in their Operations, as will be attested by numerous Patients that have committed themselves to my Care, and found extraordinary Benefit by them; when Men of greater Names, after long Tryals have been unsuccessful, to the infinite Trouble and great Expence of the Diseased; both which will be prevented by the Method I take, in a happy conjunction of Speculative and Experimental Knowledge, as the only remedy of the Inconveniencies that cramp a Suc∣cessful Practice.

The Medicines I exhibit are sure, and the Knowledge I have of their vertue, is not the effect of my Reasoning; but of my Observa∣tion, so that those that use them will find them Successful. I say, this Knowledge is not the Fruits of my Reason, because in reality it is not; and further, to set this Assertion right, it cannot be so; for in the matter of Medicines, we have no other way to follow, but that of Observation: For to offer to discover, by Reason alone, the vertue of Medicaments, is the way never to find what we seek for I theref re apply my self to Experience, and leave those Tricks and vain Subtilities, which according to Quintilian, render us like those little Insects, that are never pleas'd but when they are among Thorns and Briars. Its high time to shake off this School Physick, which is good for nothing but wrangling, and attain a positive Physick, which is of use in Practice. By po∣sitive
Physick, I don't mean one made up of Authorities, which consists in knowing the Sentiments of divers Authors upon a con∣troverted Point, as in Positive Divinity: But I mean one that consists of positive Mat∣ters of Fact, which teaches what has been often successful in the same Circumstances; and I may be bold to say, that Positive Physick, regulated by Method, is the true Physick.

School Physick, enables Practitioners to make smart Repartees, to come off hand∣somely in a controverted Point; and the other makes us sensible and Prudent, so as to order nothing but what's convenient: The out makes us Headstrong and Opinionative, and the other makes us honest Physicians, who seek for nothing but how to inform our selves, and to be useful: The one seeks for Evasons how to defend himself under a Disappointment, and the other for Medi∣cines to Cure Distempers: The one consults his Ideas, and the other consults his Reason and Experience: The one makes Pedants, and the other Physicians.

A Chymi∣cal Elixir, and its Operation.And first, my Chymical Elixir, is in its own Nature peculiarly adapted to the Cure of the Cholick, because its innate vertues are powerful in allaying Pains, taking away the Cause of the Disease, and re-invigorating the Patient's Strength, and refreshing his Spirits, by which means, and not by any Narcotick quality in the Medicine, Nature is enabled to expel the Morbifick Matter lodg d in the Nervous Plexus's of the Mesentery, and to subdue and conquer the Disease. This Elixir also is endued with an excellent Quality, to Purify the Blood and Nervous
Liquors, and keep them in a due and regular Crasis, in order to prevent the engendring of Morbifick Matter; Strengthens the Brain and the Nervous Foldings of the Abdomen, and removes the present Procatarxis of the Cholick, and hinders the Invasions of Pains for the Future, so that they shall seldom or never return afterwards.

How to be taken, and its happy Effects.Which Elixir is to be taken, Ten Drops at a time, when assaulted by Cholick Pains, in Five or Six Spoonfuls of Generous Wine, smooth clear Ale, or well brew d Table-Beer, every half Hour till the Pain is abated, and then forbear taking any more Drops for that time, unless the Pain returns. This Quantity of Drops is proper for Men; but the Fair Sex must take but Five or Six Drops at a time, in Two or Three Spoon∣fuls of either of the above mention'd Li∣quors, observing the same Rules as are given to Men. But if the Sick are enclined to Vo∣mit up whatever they take, let the Patient take the same quantity of Drops in a smaer quantity of Liquor. Some Persons of both Sexes can take a greater number of Drops than others; and in violent Fits of the Cholick, if the Patient has not ease with a small number of Drops, let them add two Drops every time they take them, till easy, then take no more that time. As to the quantity of the Drops the Patient is the proper judge, who finding what number of Drops best agrees with his Constituion, his own Reason will induce him in all Effects, to stick to that Quantity.

When either Man or Woman takes my E∣lixir in the Day time, let them lye down upo a Bed, dispose themselves to Rest, and
if they find their Stomachs any way disorder'd, the longer they repose, the sooner they will find Refreshment and Ease.

If the Sick enter into a course of taking my Elixir, to eradicate this Distemper and put a final end to his tormenting Pains, let him take Four Drops at Night when he is going to Bed, in a Glass of some, of the Vehicle afore named, or in Bohe Tea, and continue so to do, by adding One Drop every successive Night, till he has imbibed 20, 30, or 40 Drops; or at least the certain number that agrees with him, and adhere to that, till he finds himself recover'd; always lying long in Bed in the Morning, that the Elixir may the sooner produce its desired happy Effect.

An Ad∣vertise∣ment to Water-Drinkers.Further, if the Sick has at any time, found some Benefit by drinking Spaw-Water, and is desirous to continue it, because his Bowels are too Hot, let him put Six Drops of my Elixir into half a Pint of Spaw-Water, and drink it going to Bed, for a Month to∣gether; for, this Elixir is the best Medicine in the World, to make all Mineral Waters pass off well and quickly by Urine or Seige; which if they stay long in the Body, by taking up their Quarters in the Head or Feet, they will cause the Vertigo, or Gout, as is often found by dreadful Experience. Which may serve as a cautionary. Advertisement, to all that accustom themselves for Diversion or Ne∣cessity sake, to drink Tunbridge, Epsom, Dul∣lege, Kensington, Islington, North-Hall, Bath, Northampton-shire, Derby-shire, or York-shire-Waters, that they always carry a small Bottle of my Elixir along with them, for preven∣tion of such ill Accidents as frequently come
to pass, by drinking those Waters alone, and to effect more safely, certainly and speedi∣ly their Intentions in drinking those Mineral Waters, which for want of using my Elixir with them, generally prove ineffectual.

This Elixir, a name taken from the Arabick Word Eleeschir, signifying Powerful, is also effectual against the Stone, Gravel, and Bloody Urine; stops Vomiting and a Loosness, and is a proper Medicine against Chatars, Coughs, and all Diseases incident to the Head and Breast. It continues its whole Vertue in all Climates, and conse∣quently is fit to be carried, as it has been, to the East or West-Indies, to any of the Northern Countries, the Mediteranean, or the South-Seas. It will last more than Twenty Years, and no Family that has Experienc'd its Vertues in many others, as well as this Di∣stemper, will be without it.

The Au∣thor's Cor∣dia Cho∣lick Waters.And since in this Disease, all things, tho' properly enough contrived and invented, do not agree with all Persons, nor please in in the same Form of Composition, and that some Palates disrelish what others imbibe with Pleasure, so there is sometimes a Ne∣cessity of changing and altering Medicines in respect of their Form, as well as Ingre∣dients in their Composition, that they may more effectually operate upon the different vicious Humours, and on the various Parts affected.

To answer all these Ends, I invented my Cordial Anticholical Water, whose vertues far exceed the common Tincture of Steel and of Antimony and Amber, so much extoll'd in the Cure of the Cholick; because after a peculiar manner, it gives Ease by expelling
the viscous Recrements in the great Mesente∣rick Plexus, to which the Intestines are an∣nexed, and allays the griping Pains that follow the irregular Cure of Fevers, which are caus'd, by transferring the Morbifick Matter to the Glandules of the Mesentery, and the subsequent irritation of its Nerves. This Anticholical Water, or Solar Liquor, has also both a Diuretick and Carminative Quality, and has admirable effects, both in Tender and Robust Constitutions, and I often give it with great Success, either it self, or mix'd with other proper Specificks, as a Spur in Hot Discrasies of the Viscera with a pre∣dominancy of adust Sulphur, as also in Flit∣ting, Scorbutical, and irregular Boilings of the Blood and Nervous juice, which seldom or never fails of doing good in the most desperate Cases I have met with, in many Years Practice.

How to be taken.This Water is to be taken by Two or Three Spoonfuls at any time, when the Sick is grieved with the Cholick; either by it self, or put into a Glass of warm Ale, or burnt White-Wine, and being repeated as occasion requires, the Physician will accom∣plish his main end, and the Patient if he is a Person of common Ingenuity, Gratitud and Honesty, will not grudge his Expenc of Time or Money, in purchasing so effica∣cious Remedy.

The Third Nostrum I employ for the Cure of the Cholick, I call Pillulae Anticolicae, or Anticholical Pills; They are compounded of the choicest Ingredients in the whole Ma∣teria Medica, and require a long time and great Care and Pains in their Preparation, the Mass being an Extract and no common
Composition, as will appear in their Opera∣tion, and the happy effects produced by them. Now you having read in the foregoing Dis∣course, that in some Cases, and especially when the Intestines are much contracted by Viscous Matter contain'd in them, that Purg∣ing Medicines are not to be used; and that all other Cases, for the Cure of the Cholick, strong Catharticks are absolutely necessary; to avoid these extreams, I have chosen the Golden mean, and so contrived my Anticho∣lical Pills, by mixing attenuating and mol∣ifying Ingredients with Purgatives, that they will Work but gently, tho' very ef∣fectually, in order to discuss or expel the Peccant Humours by degrees, without of∣fering Violence to Nature, by being over hasty in th Cure, and to that end admini∣string over powerful Purgatives, which ra∣ther weaken the Patient, than mitigate his Pains, or diminish his Distemper. But my Pills are Hermetically compounded, and at the same time both throw out the sharp of∣fening Humours, corroborate the Stomach, fortify the Spirits, and strengthen the whole Body against the future Invasion of the Dis∣ease, as the only safe and easy way to a per∣fect Cure, which these Pills, taken accord∣ing to the following Directions, very seldom ve behind them.

Directions for taking the Pills.They are to be taken, one pill late at Night, at the time of going to Rest, every third or fourth Night, and if that Pill does not Work pretty early in the Morning, take one or two Pills more every two Hours till they Operate gently, but if it makes the Patient Sick in his Stomach, and doth not Purge him, let him Dissolve an
Ounce of Epsom Salt, or six Drams of the Le∣nitive Electuary, in a Pint of Water Gruel, or Mutton-Broath, and drink it Blood-warm, the Pills will have the same effect, if they are forced to be purg'd off; Two, Three, or Four Stools is sufficient for one time: Keep very warm, and drink nothing cold that Day. After taking them, let the Sick drink large draughts of thin Chicken Broath, Mutton Broath, or Water Gruel, or for want of them Posset Drink, to dilute the sharp Humours, cast them out, or their A∣crimony being taken off, reduce them to a better Temper: Which you will soon find, if this Course is duly repeated, as often as there is occasion, and when there is none, take no more Pills, for I don't give them for Lucre of Money, but to answer the In∣tention of Healing, for therein consists my Interest. These Pills are good for the Scurvy, Pains in any part of the Body, King's Evil, corrupt Humours in any Part of the Body, the Itch, Leprofie, Old Ulcers, Worms, Gravel, Stones and in other Cases where Purging is necessary.

The Fourth Remedy.Those Days wherein the Patient does not Purge, I give a Cordial Electuary, which I call Electuarium Anticolica, or my Anticholical Electuary, which is the Fourth Remedy for the Cure of this Disease, and which seldom fails, if the Disease is Cureable, this Electuary being indued with such rare, uncommon and well experiencd Vertues, agreeable to the Dictates of Nature and Art, and so signifi∣cantly adapted to the Cure of the Cholick, in all its various kinds, where purging is ne∣cessary or unnecessary and dangerous, that the Patient will seldom be perfectly cured with∣out
it; because as I have found by repeated Experience, that when all other Remedies prescribed by the best Hands have been in∣effectual, this Electuary has done the Work, by corroborating the Stomach, correcting its vicious Fermentation, retrieving its depraved Appetite, and restoring its almost lost Tone to a regular and sanative Crasis.

Directions for taking this Ele∣ctuary.This Electuary is sometimes also to be taken in the Morning on an empty Sto∣mach: Its Dose is about the quantity of a Nutmeg, fasting an Hour after it, and again at Four or Five in the Afternoon, for 10, 15, 20, or 30 Days, when you use no Purgatives. Eat what Dyet is most nourishing and sits light upon the Stomach, and abstain from nothing so much as Milk and Stale Beer. And now I might be Very Copious, in the Commendation and Praise of these Four Re∣medies, invented by, and I believe only known to my self, and are disposed of at no Place, but my Dwelling-House; but that Persons who know me not, may not think I harangue to promote my own Profit in selling them, I shall wave it for the present, and leave every Man that buys and uses them, to give them what Character they Deserve. And from hence I pro∣ceed to Observations, and Examples of Per∣sons cured of the Cholick, by the regular use of my afore named Remedies of which its needless to give you great Numbers, tho' I am plentifully furnish'd with them; because the Publick bas almost Weekly notice of Persons cured by me in
Certificates under the Hands of my Patiens, well attested, and Printed in the Publick News Papers.

Examples of Persons Cured.A Gentlewoman of good Reputation, ex∣treamly afflicted with the Cholick for many Years, after she had taken, as she thought, the best Advice that could be given in Lon∣don, was recommended to my Care for the Cure of her Cholick. A Tradesman in the City of London, who had suffer'd intolerable Cholical Pains, and had taken several Medicines from his own Physitian and Apothecary for a considerable time, was induced to apply himself to me, and I gave him Ease immediately, and in a very short time after, perfectly cured him. The Cholick in the Sto∣mach.Having now finish'd what I had to say of an Accidental Cholick, according to the Me∣thod proposed, I am obliged to treat of the Cholick as complicated or joined with other Diseases, and that which leads the Van, is the Stomachical Chotick, and that very justly, because the Minera of all Chronical Dis∣eases are to be sought in the Stomach: And if the upper Orifice of it, which is of exquisite Sense, by reason of the intermixture of Nerves, with which it is plentifully furnish'd from the vaga sexta, Branches whereof being communicated to the Heart, that noble part being affected, then the Disease is called in Greek vel , and in Latin Cardiacus dolor, the Pain of the Heart; but if the lower Orifice called Pylorus be affected, it is called Dolor, seu Colica Ventriculi, Pain, or the Cholick in the Stomach, more especially if it proceed from Wind.

Causes of the Cholick in the Sto∣mach.The Internal Causes of this Disease, some∣times proceed from great Oppletion and Pain of the Stomach, sometimes from frequent and violent Vomiting, which arises from the Chyle there degenerated into a Mass of Cor∣ruption; but oftner from the Morbifick Matter brought thither, either by the con∣veyance of the Blood, or also of the Nervous Juice, and either deposed within the Cavity of the Stomach, or fix'd in the Plexus's of the Nerves, and in the Membranes appertaining to it. Sometimes Worms gnawing the Tunicles of the Stomach cause this Disease, or Wind
lodg'd in the Cavity of the Stomach, which causes Swellings and painful Distension, or from sharp Phlegm or Green and Black Choler; whose sharp Vapours cause Pain, or from cor∣rupt Matter from an Imposthume in the Liver, or the Breast, Diseases of the Stomach, and Parts adjoining; ill Humours from the whole Body as in Fevers, Choler from the Liver, Me∣lancholly from the Spleen, Salt Phlegm from the Head; all these may be the Causes of the Cho∣lick in the Stomach.

The External Causes of this Malady, may be corrupt Nourishment, Viands too Hot that breed Wind or Choler: Meat taken in too large quantity, Poyson, or strong sharp and dangerous Medicines uncorrected.

Symptoms of the Cho∣lick in the Stomach.Diagnostick Signs, are, Pain in the Ensi∣formis, or lower part of the Breast-Bone, which signifie that the upper Orifice of the Stomach is affected with very sharp Pain, that will not suffer the Patient to take any Rest, and sometimes cause an inveterate Headach, the Megrim, Vertigo and the Epi∣lepsy. In the other Parts of the Stomach the Symptoms are not so violent, but are truly Cholical, and exactly resemble that Disease in its utmost Latitude.

Prognostick Symptoms are ominous, for this Disease is more dangerus than any other Dis∣ease of the Stomach, and the Danger is greater if it is accompanied with a Fever, for in such a case, according to Hippocrates, Death is at hand. Its least dangerous if it proceeds from Worms; tho' even in that, sometimes dangerous Symptoms appear and the Patient dies. In short, the Prognosticks are usually the Symptoms of Hypocondriack Illness; and if they happen upon the recovery of a Disease,
portends its relapse; if they come from Wind that cannot be removed a Dry Dropsie fol∣lows. If they stink horribly, they are very Malignant and Contagious.

Cure of a Cholick in the Sto∣mach.The method of Curing a Stomachical Cho∣lick, if it be not grown Obstinate, Inveterate, and beyond the Power of Medicines to give Relief, is by considering the Cause of the Disease, to prescribe Medicines that are pro∣per to remove it.

If Wind is the Cause, Carminative Clysters are exhibited, to discuss it and moderate the violent Pains in the Stomach caused by it: And if the Wind be accompanied with flush∣ings in the Face and excessive Heat, Spirit of Nitre dulcisied with Spirit of Wine, and impreg∣nated with the Vertue of Carminative Simples after Sylvius's Method, is said to be an incomparable Remedy. Inveterate acid Belchings are put off, by five or six Pepper Corns being taken every Morning Fasting. If the Wind proceed from a thick, stubborn Mucilage, Asthmatical Syrups, and Michael's Elixir for the Stomach are very proper; to which you may add Externally, Fomentations with Oil of Chamomel, and of the Carminative Seeds: Or with a mixture of Ani∣seed-Water, Spirit of Wine Camphorated and Treacle.

If a Viscous stinking, or otherwise offen∣sive matter be cast up by Vomit, and there be suspicion that the Cause lies in the Cavity of the Stomach, 'tis proper to give a gentle Vomit, of Wine of Squills, or of Salt of Vitriol; or the offending Humours may be purg'd off by Stool, by Stomachical Catharticks adapted pro re nata. But if the Matter sticks deeply and firmly within the Membranes, or foldings of the Nerves, Diaphoreticks or Specificks that
moderate the effervescencies of the Salts are more prevalent, and ought to be administred at proper times, as the Physician employ'd hall find occasion: Not forgetting, twice or thrice a Day to apply Fomentations to the Region of the Stomach, with Woolen Cloths dipt in the warm'd Liquid Medicine last above named, and wrung forth; for that will much contribute to the abatement of the Patient's griping, intolerable Pains.

The Au∣thor's own Medicines.But to return from this Digression, the Method I have shewn in the general practice of Physick, by the best Physicians of the present Age, in the foregoing Paragraphs, is what I observe my self, tho' the Medicines I give are entirely of my own Inventing, Compounding and Preparing, and the Effi∣cacy whereof I can rely upon for a Cure, (if curable) of this dangerous Disease; for tho' in all Cholical Distempers my Elixir, Cho∣lick-Water, Pills and Electuary, will have their Turns, yet am I not unprovided of other

For these Reasons and because in Sto∣machical Cholicks, proceeding from Viscous stinking Matter lodg'd in the Cavity of the Stomach, a Vomit seems absolutely neces∣sary, to dislodge the offending Humour; I am always provided of an Emetick of such an universal Vertue, that it answers all the Intentions of Nature and Art in Vomiting, and leaves no Relicks for another Invasion behind it. The Hy∣sterical Cholick.This Disease being commonly known by the tormenting Pains that always accompany it, might reasonably save me the labour of giving, and my Reader the loss of time in perusing them: However, in compliance with my Promise, I shall give him one of the many Observations I have made, and Ex∣amples I am able to produce.

John Gregory Cabinet-Maker, in Philip-Lane, in the Parish of St. Alphage, near London-Wall, being grieved with the Cholick in his Stomach, attended with extraordinary Pain in the Ensiformis, or lower part of the Breast Bone; which was sufficient reason to induce me to be of Opinion, that the upper Orifice of the Stomach was affected; and giving him proper Medicines of my own, he no sooner took them according to my Di∣rections, but he found ease immediately, and continuing the use of them a very short time, he was restored to his former Health, and was able to follow his Business, which he was uncapable of doing for Five Months time, before he applied himself to me, tho' he had taken many Medicines of others, without receiving any Benefit by them; but now enjoys perfect Health, the only comfort of Life.

This Disease, called by the Greeks , and by the Latins Ʋteri Stangulatio
or Colica Hystericalis, the Histerical Cholick, or Fits of the Mother, is not to be imputed to the Ascent or Rising of the Womb, accord∣ing to the vulgar expression: Nor to the Impetuous rushing of the Blood into the Lungs; for the effect truly called Hysterical, is chiefly and primarily Convulsive, and de∣pends principally on the Brain and genus Nervosum being affected, and is produced by the explosion of the Animal Spirits as are other Convulsive Motions, and whatever disorder or irregularities happen else about the motion of the Blood they are only Se∣condary and depend on the Convulsions of the Viscera. Nor is this Disease only frequent, but so strangely various, that it resembles almost all the Diseases poor Mortals are in∣clin'd to, and generally ends in an Hemiplegy, a Palsey on one side, below the Head, which obstructs the Animal Spirits in their passage, and is exactly like an Appoplexy; whereby corpulent and old People are destroyed, be∣cause the Cortex of the Brain is stopt by a super abundance of Phlegm. In the violent Convulsions that happen in an Hysterical Cholick, Women seem to have the Falling Sickness, and sometimes struggle so violently, that tho' at other times their Strength is but ordinary, they can scarce be held by all the united Strength of those that are about them.

Pathogno∣mick Sym∣toms.The Symptoms of this Disease are various and manifold, and seldom agree in divers Women, or happen wholly in the same man∣ner: The most common are, Malignant Vapours, excessive stretching or tearing Pain under the short Ribs, a motion in the lower part of the Belly, and an Ascent, as it were,
of some round thing there, falsly imputed to the Womb, then a Belching or straining to Vomit, a distention of the Hypocondres, and a rumbling with a Belching forth of Wind, an uneven and for the most part short Breath, a Suffocation in the Throat, a Giddiness, an, inversion or rolling of the Eyes, often Laugh∣ing or Weeping or Talking Idly; sometimes a speechlessness and Immobility, with an obscure or no Pulse, and a Cadaverous Countenance. Women of all Ages and Conditions are Ob∣noxious to this Disease, Rich and Poor, Vir∣gins, Wives, Widows, and sometimes those Symptoms appear in Girls before Puberty, and sometimes in Old Woman after their Menses are ceased; and some learned Phy∣sicians tells us, that even Men are sometimes troubled with such kind of Passions. But,

Tho' the Hysterical Cholick often rises from the Brain, yet sometimes it comes by a Cause beginning either in the Womb, or in other parts or the Viscera, and in whatever part it seats it self, it presently produces such Symptoms as belong to it, and unless the Phy∣sician is very Skilful, he will be mistaken, and think those Symptoms come from some Essential Distemper of this or that Part, and not from an Hysterick Cholick; therefore the Symptoms are best taken from the Part af∣fected. But among all the Diagnostick Signs of an Hysterical Cholick, this is most proper and almost inseparable, viz. an Ʋrine as clear as Rock-Water, which Hysterical Women evacuate most plentifully, and is in almost all of them the Pathognomick Sign of this Disease, which we call Hsterical in Women and Hypocondriacal in Men; and Women and
Men seldom Recover, till the Citron colour'd Urine returns to its Amber colour.

Progno∣stick Sym∣ptoms.If the Female Patient, is extraordinarily troubled with Cholick griping Pains and in∣cessant Vomitings, joined with strong Con∣vulsive Fits, her Menses stopt, undergoing violent Contractions and Convulsions, about the parts of the Mouth, and Face, and Arms, and Legs, with a Pale, Wan Countenance and trembling as she walks, and growing every Day worse than other, her Case is very Dangerous and seldom or never admits of Cure: But if the Convulsions cease, by administring proper Medicines, adapted to Cholick Pains and Fits of the Mother in Con∣junction; Vapours ascending from the Womb are expell'd, and the Menses orderly flow, they are hopeful Indications.

The Procatartick or External Causes of this complicated Disease,Causes of an Hyste∣rical Cho∣lick. are violent motions of the Body, or which is oftner and worse, violent Perturbations of the Mind from some sudden assault, either of Anger or Grief, or such like Passions, especially as I have said already, if Ʋrine clear as Christal evacuated copiousl at some certain times, makes the Diagnostick more manifest. But to these Disorders of the Mind, which are usually the Cause of this Disease, Emptiness of the Sto∣mach by reason of long Fasting, is to be added, and immoderate Bleeding, a Vomit or Purge that has wrought too much. Now having drawn the Picture of this Disease, ac∣cording to its vulgar Phenomena; in the next place, the Internal, Efficient Causes are to be considered, as well as I can gather them from all the Circumstances joined together: And in my Opinion this Disease that I call
an Hsterical Cholick, proceeds from a stoppage of the Menses, a confusion of the Animal Spirits, when too many of them, and contrary to due proportion are violent∣ly burried upon this or that part, causing Convulsions and Pains, when they rush up∣on Parts of Exquisite Sense; to which the causes of a Simple Cholick being added, you have the true Causes of this Disease.

The general method for the Cure of this Disease, is, first to give present Ease in the Paroxisms, and then proceed to a Cure. To accomplish both these Intentions, 'tis usual in the first place to apply stinking and strong smelling things to the Nostrils, the Effluvia's of which, repress and reduce to order the Spirits which are grown too Wild, and apt to make exorbitant efforts; nay, and discuss their Heterogeneous combination, and often wholly exterminate it. Assa Faetida, Casto∣reum, Galbanum, tyed in a fine Cloth and held to the Nostrils are proper; also Par∣tridges Feathers, or old Shoes burnt, or Sul∣phur kindled; also the Spirit and Oil of Soot and Harts-horn often give Ease; but the chief Indication in this Disease, is to strengthen the Blood which is the fountain of the Spirits; which being done, the invigorated Spirits can preserve that order which is agreeable to the Oeconomy of the whole Body, and the particular Parts. And therefore when the Ataxy of the Spirits has vitiated the Hu∣mours by long continuance, you must first lessen the Humours so corrupted, by bleeding and Purging if the Patient has sufficient strength, before you endeavour to invigo∣ate the Blood; and which indeed you can
scarce do, whilst a faeculent heap of Humours lye in the way.

If there be room for a Vomit, you must always begin with that, especially in Caco∣chmical Persons in whom a mighty load of Viscous Phlegm sticking to the Folds and Coats of the Stomach, hinders the Vertues of other Medicines. In a few Days after the Vomit, unless somewhat indicates the contrary; in Women of a Hot Tempera∣ment open a Vein in the Arm presently, or afterward if need be take Blood from the Foot, or the Fundament by Leeches, and after these Evacuations duly performed: always provided they be indicated, let a Purge be given three or four Mornings after. Then to strengthen the Blood, and consequently support the Spirits, let Chalybeates be ex∣hibited to raise a Volatile Ferment in the Va∣pid and Languid Blood, that the Spirits may be roused, which before were press'd down by their own Weight. These Di∣rections I think sufficient, without prescri∣bing particular Medicines or their Doses, for he that does not understand what Me∣dicines are proper, in every Disease, the quantity to be given, and the manner How, and the time When, is unfit to practise Phy∣sick; and for those who do not pretend to that Skill, they may have experimented Me∣dicines of me in most Diseases, if they ei∣ther please to come themselves, or send their Cases in Writing, or by an Intelligent Messenger.

The Scor∣butick Cho∣lick. Colica Scorbuticus, or the Scorbutick Cholick. There's a sort of Cachexy reigning in our Northern Clymats, whose Symptoms chiefly appearing in the Hypochondria, is called the Hypocondriack Evil, and when its Symptoms are very fierce and exalted, 'tis named the Scurvy: An Apellation given it by the Saxons in North Germany, who are generally afflict∣ed with it. 'Tis a busie, intermedling, en∣croaching Disease, that now mingles almost
with all Chronical Distempers, and passes in∣conceivably into all parts of the Body; which caused Helmant to say of complicated Effects, that per ignorata seminaria, & initia invisibilia, by unknown Seminaries, and in visible Beginnings, which is certainly true, for in these latter times new Diseases have started up, which were unknown to the Antients; because they have put on other strange Sym∣ptoms and Properties, Quibus larvati incedunt, with which they walk disguised and deceive such Physicians, as think to Cure Diseases by following the Directions and Precepts of the Antients, who knew little or nothing of the unaccountable Mixtures, Complications and Disguises, which we daily see; and yet some are so sottish to confine themselves to such superannuated exploded Definitions, Notions and Medicines as they have left us, who pra∣ctised when Diseases were but few, more single, calm and gentle, and more tractable and curable than at this Day, when its rare to sind an uncomplicated Disease, in which the Blood and other Humours are not viti∣ated, by being unhappily mix'd with other unseen Maladies.

Now because the Scurvy is a lurking Dis∣ease, and consumes the Patient by insensible or slow degrees, and its direful effects are never so much perceived or felt, as when it intermixes it self with other Diseases, so its seldom regarded as the principal Offender, but the the Disease is chiefly attributed to the Concommitant Distemper that causes Pain. So it often happens, that a continued latent Scurvy is little observed, but when its joined with the Cholick that causes griping tormenting Pains, the Disease is called a Cholick,
and Remedies used accordingly without Suc∣cess, because the Scurvy was neglected, tho' scarce any effect requires a more speedy Physical help, than the Cholick and Gripes of the Besly occasion'd by the Scurvy, which makes them more violent, and of longer continuance, by obstinately resisting the Methods of Cure.
In the Symptoms of the Scorbutick Cholick,Symptoms of the Scorbutick Cholick. I shall be very brief, having been very large on that Head in the foregoing Cholicks.

The usual Signs are, high colour'd Urine or precipitating a Red Sandy Flesh colour'd Sediment, or fastens red friable Sand upon the sides of the Urinal. Continual Pain of the Head, Palpitation of the Heart, puffing up of the Stomach, loathing, Vomiting, Belching, Hiccough, Cough, Tumors and Putrefaction of the Gums with much Spitting; Looseness and blackness of the Teeth, (for the Cure of which I have a Dentefrice which makes the Teeth as White as Ivory,) the Breath stinks, and is sometimes fetch'd with great difficulty, and is seldom free from terrible Pains of the Cholick, and trembling and looseness of the Joints and Limbs, with Laziness and often Faint Sweats; there is also sometimes Malignant Ʋlcers, dry hard Tubercles, Erisipelas, and Oedematous Tumors, with many others, which to enumerate, were to comprehend an universal Genus of Atoms within a very narrow Limitation.

This Disease is very hard to cure, where the Scorbutick Humour is obdurate and pre∣dominant, and when the Cure has been too long delayed, or not treated as a complicated Disease, many times 'tis very Dangerous, the Pains of the Cholick may run into an incurable
Iliack Passion, and its sullen Companion, may bring a Dropsie, a Consumption, or other Mor∣tal Chronical Distempers, and sometimes Acute Diseases, as the Appoplexy Swooning, or the like; which produce sudden Death.

Causes of a Scorbu∣tick Cho∣lick.The Immediate causes of this Disease, is, a volatile Acid, that irritates the Nerves and Membranes, sharpens the Lympha, debauches the innate Spirits of the Parts, and perverts the equal temperature of the Blood. The Remote Causes, are, Sea Air impregnated with Salin, Acid Vapours, Salt and Viscous Food, Laziness, Weakness of Digestion, Infection, a Hereditary Conveyance, and the influence of Chronical Diseases. If the Disease is recent it admits of Cure. If inveterate, it requires a continued use of proper Medicines for a long space of time.

Cure of a Scorbutick Cholick.The Cure of a Scorbutick Cholick, consists, in correcting and evacuating the Crudities of the first Passages, fortifying the Stomach, re∣trieving the due Crasis of the Blood, restoring all wonted Evacuations to their former Course, and to appease excruciating Pains. In order then to compass these Ends, and Cure this stubborn and rebellious Disease, the Sick must observe a good Diet, without which Physical means will profit but little: And here, because in the first place there will be a necessity (if possible) to give Ease in the Fit by Opiates, let them always be ac∣companied by Antiscorbutick Specificks, of which may be prepared diversity of good Medicines, both Chymical and Galenical. The Volatile Salts both of Animals and Vegitables are excellent to open all Obstructions, and Temper the Humours; also, Elixir Proprie∣tatis, the Spirit of Sal Armoniack, the Spirit
of Nitre, and of Salt Dulcified, Salt of Steel, Wormwood and Tartar, Oil of Juniper, Cloves and Cinamon, are all Antiscorbutick Spe∣cificks.

Next in order are gentle Laxitives, espe∣cially in Hot Constitutions; such are Pills of Armoniacum, or those of Tartar mix'd with sweet Mercury, to prevent or take a∣way Costiveness. Resinous Purgatives are to be avoided, as beings endow'd with an A∣stringent Quality. Raisins, Prunes, Tamarinds, and Ripe sweet Apples, or their express'd Juice are of considerable Efficacy in this Case; but Sugar and other sweet things ought to be carefully avoided. Rhubarb or Cream of Tartar, sharpened with Pouder of Jalap, are proper for such as are of a Moist Juicy Con∣stitution.

The Patient's Body being thus prepared, you ought to proceed to Alteratives, such are Steel and all fix'd Salts, or whatever subdues an Acid. To which join Aperient, Diureticks and bitter Stomachical Aromaticks, or the Spirituous Volatile Salts, Mynsichts Arcanūm Duplicatum, is of excellent use, especially when the Sick is troubled with Flushings and sudden Inflamations. Elixir Proprietatis pre∣pared with an Acid and mix'd with the Spi∣rit of Scurvigrass, and that of Sal Armoniac is also proper. The Tincture of Tartar mix'd with the Spirit of Sal-Armoniack, and given by degrees to Forty Drops, is a celebrated Medicine. And as you find occasion, Fo∣mentations, Ligatures, Ventoses, Sternuta∣tories, &c. are of use.
