The Iliack Passion.I his Disease called in Greek in Latin Iliaca Passio, from the Gut Ileon, which is chiefly affected in this Distemper, is a Cholick in excess, an extream Costiveness, pain about the Navel, rising from the inverted Peristaltick motion of the Guts, disgorging the Excrements upward; for the Fibres of the Guts which ought to be contracted from e Superior towards the Inferior, are drawn to the Superior; so whatsoever is contained in the Guts is Vomited up, and Clysters how sharp so ever become Vomitive: Purges also taken by the Mouth are cast up by Vomit; and I am of Opinion, that the exquisite and intollerable Pain coming upon this Disease, is only occasion'd by the aforesaid Preposterous motions of the Guts; for as those Folds which the many Circumvolutions of the Guts make, are so formed by Nature, that they should most aptly conduce to the car∣rying, down of the Feces; when they are forced to give way to a motion contrary to their Fibres, the aforesaid Pain is occasion'd from thence, which is fix'd to one Part, and is like the boaring of an Augur, when ei∣ther the value, which is seated at the be∣ginning of the Colon, hinders the going back of the Excrements to the Ilium, or any o∣ther Membrane belonging to the Sinus, sustains alone the force of this Peristaltick motion.

Symptoms of an Iliack Passion.The Signs of an approaching Iliack Passion, are, extream Costiveness, retraction of the Anus, a Loathing, Vomiting and intollerable Pains in the small Guts; and if a Hiccough follow it, threatens Death. If the Anus is much drawn back, so that a Clyster-Pipe can∣not enter it, 'tis a sign that the gross In∣testiness are affected. If otherwise the small Guts are touched. If the greatest Pain possesses the Epigastrium, the Ilium is most oppress'd. A shooting burning Pain in one particular part of the Body, a Lipyria Fever. If the Pain ceasing is attended by cold Sweats, difficult Respiration, Swoonings, and sometimes Convulsions, 'tis a Sign of a Gangrene, caused by the corrugation of the Guts, mistaken by some for a twisting of 'em round one another, a thing inconsistent with their Ligation to the Mesentery. In fine, the common Symptoms of an Iliack Passion, are hardness of the Belly, suppression of the Ʋrine, Loathing, Vomiting, first the contents of the Stomach, and next the Excrements, a stinking habit of Body, fre∣quent Swoonings, insufferable griping Pains in the Guts, a prodigious Anxiety, and some∣times Vomiting of Clysters.

Progno∣stick Signs.In the Prognosticks of an Iliack Passion, n∣flamations or Gangreenes are Mortal. If the upper Gut descend in the lower 'tis a fatal Symptom. If the lower ascend into the higher, 'tis curable. If the Disease proceed from a Rupture or hardened Excrements, 'tis not desperate. If Sleep succeeds the taking of Opiates, 'tis a hopeful Indication. Deafness or Dotings are pernicious consequences. If the Sweat, Breath, and Belching stink very much, Death is about to put an End to the Patient's Misery.

Causes of the Iliack Passion.The Cause of an Ileos, or Iliaca Passio, is a excrementitious Viscous Matter, adhering to the Gut Ileo, which in time is coagulated into a very hard substance, almost in the Form of Bullets, whence all the passage for Excrements by siege is stop'd, and anon their regress and ascent to the Stomach fol∣lows, with a miserable Vomiting of them up.

The Rupture of the Peritoneum may cause this grievous Disease, especially if it be so great, that not only the small Guts but the great ones also, fall through the lacerated Orifice, and renders them uncapable of be∣ing reduced or put back through the same Hole; so that a hard and unsupportable Tu∣mor follows, which hinders the Reflux of Blood, and causes an Inflamation, and con∣sequently a Gangrene in the Guts, attended with a violent Vomiting of the Excrements and a speedy summons to the Grave.

But we may chiefly assign a twofold Cause of this Inversion, from whence the Pain arises, and they are Obstruction and Irritation; for whatever violently obstructs the Intestines, so that nothing can pass downwards, necessa∣rily occasions this contrary Motion in them, as hardned Excrements, gross Wind col∣lected in great quantity, &c. Irritation pro∣ceeds from sharp and Malignant Humours cast upon the Stomach and Guts that are next to it, by the excessive raging of the Blood, by reason of a late Fever begun, whereby the motion of the Stomach is first Inverted, and violently forced to cast up what is contained in it; at length the small Guts that are joined to the Stomach being weakned, yield to the violent Motion of it,
and with them at last the greater follow by consent; the Stomach Vomiting beginning the fatal Tragedy: And this may be truly call'd the Iliack Passion.

The cure of this Disease, consists in re∣moving the Irritation, and retrieving the Natural Motion of the Guts, to that end if the Excrements are harden'd they ought to be soften'd by the speedy exhibition of Clysters, before they are hardened beyond Re∣lief. All Purgatives are improper, till the Pain in the Guts and Stomach are quieted, and restored to their Natural Motion, which you may know, by a large quantity of Hu∣mours being voided downwards by the help of Nature or Art. Opiates are very hurtful in case of a Gangrene and in that of Obstructions, till the Belly is well opened; but if the Dis∣ease proceed from violent Irritations, attend∣ed by continual vomiting, Opiates may be mix'd with Stomachical Medicines while the Patient is strong: Always remembring, that what∣ever you use in the Cure of this Disease, whether outwardly or inwardly, must be Warm, both in the Fit, and when the Patient is on the mending hand.

If the Small Guts only are inverted, give Emollient Clysters, quickned with Sal Gem, or the Infusion of Crocus Metallorum, or those of the Carminative Seeds boiled in Childs Urine and Water: But if the great ones are also Inverted, that sort of Clysters are noxious, and you must seek help from tem∣perate, Laxative, lubrical Potions; such as the Decoction of Emollient Herbs in Broath, mix'd with Oil of Sweet Almonds newly drawn.

When all other Medicines want Success, some Men give Leaden Bullets, and boast of the use of Quicksilver, which I have seldom known to have done much good, but often prove injurious, especially in an Inflamation, Rupture, Gangrene, or falling of the upper Gut into the lower; therefore if any Practitioner thinks himself under a necessity of using Quicksilver, which is prefered before Bullets, let him be sure to prepare his Patient's Body before he gives it, with lubric al Medi∣cines, such as Oil of Sweet Almonds new drawn, or Sperma Caeti: Then exhibit Three, Four, and sometimes Eight Ounces of purified Quicksilver, together with Oil of Sweet Al∣monds and Mint Water; and if it does not answer his Intentions at first, let it be fre∣quently repeated, and the mean while inject Emollient Clysters, foment the Belly with softning Decoctions; or set the Sick into a pro∣per Bath. If the Mercury does not force its way out of the Body, give sharp Clysters, and anoint the Belly with Oil of Coloquintida to soften the Excrements. If the Quicksilver offend the Mouth, Throat and Gums, check its virulence with a Gargarism of Honey of Roses, and Syrup of Violets; and if the Mercury is successful in opening the Body, remember to exhibit the Lunar Bezoar and Diaphoretick Antimony, to expel the remains of the Mer∣cury; for tho' Mercury given by an Intelligent Person is an Excellent Medicine, yet it always does Mischief, if any of it stays too long in the Body.

These are the usual Methods for disco∣vering the Cause and curing this Disease, which I publish in this succinct way; First, to assist those that want greater Light; Se∣condly
to shew, that I am thoroughly in∣structed in the Knowledge of Physick; and, Thirdly, to silence Malicious Back-biters, who for want of business, make it part of their employment, to represent me in their ow Class of Ignoramus's which this Treatise, a the rest that are to follow it, will plainly confute, in the Opinion of all Men of Sense, Generosity and Learning.

In my own Practice for the Cure of this Disease, when it evidently appears by the Symptoms above-named, and by Vomiting up Clysters, that its a true Iliack Passion, I apply my self to give the Patient some Ease, if it be possible; for let others say what they please, he that can do that has half conquer'd the Disease, for then Nature will assist in removing the Cause, by being enabled to sustain the Force of Medicines proper to soften the Excrements, and after to expel them by Siege: And to this end, I give my Elixir in small Doses, repeat them often, and enlarge the number of Drops every time they are given, and I never found them unsuccessful; their Vertue being to invigorate the Sick by giving him a relaxation from his Pain, Mollifying the offending Matter, and by that means preparing and smoothing the way for my Pills to drive it out by gentle degrees; for this Disease will endure no rough and violent Treatment.

Here I cannot, according to Custom, give Examples of Persons Cured by the use of my Two above-named Remedies; (one I cured some∣time since, but am not permitted to make use of her Name,) for tho', blessed be God, I have never wanted Success, yet I could
not prevail with the Patients I have Cured, to give me leave to Name them, and so the Credit of my Medicines in this Case, can have no other Vouchers but my own Word and Reputation, which I value my self more upon than Ten Thousand Testimonials.

The Cae∣liack Cho∣lick.Called in Greek , in Latin Caeliaca Passio, the Caeliack Passion, or Caeliack Cholick, is a Looseness of the Belly, when the Meat comes forth crude and imperfectly digested; which some say is not to be refered to the Concoction only being hurt, but to the debility of the Retentive Faculty, the Food being not long enough retained to be Concocted; by which it appears, say they, that the Disease proceeds from a fault in the Stomach as well as in the Guts: But the Learned Etmullerus, says, it is a Flux of the Belly, by which the Chyle is voided together with Excrements, the Stomach being in no fault, because Chy∣lification is duly perform'd there; therefore the blame, says he, must either be laid on the Bile, that is stopt in its Passage to the Guts, or by degenerating from its Saline Acrimony, and consequently is unfit to se∣perate the Chyle: Or else on the Lacteal Vessels through which the Chyle ought to pass, their Orifices being covered With Slime, or shut by the Contraction, or Corrosion of the Intestines occasion'd by Fluxes.

Symptoms of a Cae∣liaca.The Symptoms of this Disease, are, extra∣orinary, Pains both in the upper and lower Region of the Belly, not unattended with Pain in the Back and Limbs; for all compli∣cated Diseases, generally affect all the Neigh∣bouring Parts, as well as the Place where they are more particularly and chiefly seat∣ed;
and that you may have a true notion of this Maladay, observe, that if the Bile is defective, the Excrements are White, or very Pale; without any sign of separation. If the obstruction of the Lacteal Veins cause the Disease, the Excrements are Yellowish, and the Chyle, tho' voided at the same time with them, is but loosely mix'd with them, as being separated in the Guts, but disappointed in its Passage.

Causes of a Coaliack Cholick.The Causes of this Distemper, are gene∣rally rank'd under Three Heads, which will comprehend all the differing Opinions about it. The First is a Cold Distemper of the Sto∣mach and Liver, which generate Phlegmatick and Glutinous Humours, which cover the Wrincles of the Stomach that it cannot retain the Food: Tho' Retention be made by the Astringing Quality, yet it operates by fit In∣struments, viz. the rawness of the Inward Coat of the Stomach; which rawness being taken away, and the Wrincles filled by the Humours aforesaid, the Retention is damni∣fied, and the Food Slips away without Con∣coction.
The Second Cause assigned by others, is, violent sharp Humours, that prick, twinge, and irritate the Parts, by which the Sto∣mach and Guts are provoked to send out the Meat too soon.

The Third, and which I take to be the true Cause of the Caeliack Cholick, is, the Obstruction of the Mesenteraick Veins which hinder the passage of the Chyle to the Liver, or the Obstruction of the Glandules of the Mesentery, and therefore must of necessity be ejected by the Belly. If this: Disease is of long continuance 'tis very dangerous, be∣cause
Nature is deprived of her Nourishment, and the Weak Body is liable to the Insults of all Diseases.

Now, since the Disease called , a Lientary, is also a Flux of the Belly, in which the Food is quickly thrown out of the Body undigested; and differs only from a Caeliack Cholick in degrees, and that their Cures are the same; I shall omit treating particu∣larly on that Head, and refer the Reader to what follows.

Cure of the Caelick Cholick.The Curatory Indication of the Caeliack Choliack, is, to remove the Morbisick Cause, and strengthen the Stomach, which kind of Method being seasonably begun, and duly prosecuted often does the whole Work; for the Cause of the Disease or the Root of it being cut off, the Effects depending on it, die of their own accord. Therefore if the Bile is sluggish, or stopp'd in its Passage, means must be used to make it more Active, to correct the Acid and Austure Ferment pro∣ceeding from the Stomach and Intestines, to retrieve the Natual Texture and distribu∣tion of the Bile and to promote the Separation of the Heterogenious Particles. If the Lacteal or Milky Vessels are shut up, endeavour to remove the Slime that choaks them, by at∣tenuating, opening Ingredients, Astringents are improper. Let the Peccant humours be purged: After which the Tincture of Tartar, or of the Dross of Regules of Antimony, or Chalybeate Tinctures, mix'd with the Spirit of Sal Armoniaci, are very convenient to strengthen the Stomach by procuring an Appetite. Amatus Lusitanus highly commends the following Prescription. Conserve of Roses six Ounces, Venice Treacle six Drams, and Syrup
of Quinces a sufficient quantity to make an Opiate: Halt an Ounce of which must be taken in the Morning, fasting an Hour after it.
For the Use and Benefit of my own Pa∣tients, I have stated and well experienc'd Medicines for the Cure of this Disease, which I could give numerous Examples, tho' I only prodnce Two.

The Cho∣lerick Cho∣lick.This Disease named in Greek and in Latin Cholerica Passio, is a Grier, in which the Vicious Humours are impetuously thrown
out both by Vomit and Stool, with a violent Pain in the Stomach and Belly, Distension of the Hypocondria, Heartburnings, Thirst, Perplexity of the Breast, a swift and some∣times Small Pulse, frequent Swoonings, a cold∣ness in the outward Parts, Prostration of Strength, and at last Convulsions and Hiccoughs. This Disease, some say, is a Symptom of the Expulsive Faculty being hurt by uncocted Meats, and if the Retentive Faculty is also in fault, the Distemper is so much the worse and more violent.

Immedi∣ate Causes of a Cho∣lerick Cho∣lick.Some make two sorts of this Disease, a Wet and a Dry, and from hence came the vulgar Distinction of Moist and Dry Gripes. A Moist is what I am discoursing. The Dry is more rarely found, proceeds from a Windy Spirit, produced in the Stomach, by the fiery Heat of the part corrupting the Meat, or by Meats Rank and Windy, as Hipocrates himself affirms. Senuertus from the Hermeti∣cal Doctrine, adds another cause, namely, Salt and adust Humours in the Hpochondria, which grow Hot by the mixture of ano∣ther Humour, and demonstrates it, by the mixing Aqua Fortis and Oil of Vitriol with Salt of Tartar, which produce very flatuous Spirits: So that according to these Authors, the Immediate Causes of this Disease, are, Cholerick, Burnt, Sharp, Salt or Rotten Humours of the Stomach, Bowels, Spleen and Mesentery; or some Nourishment of a per∣nicious Quality, or some strong Medicine or Poison, taken uncorrected.

Oasional Causes.The Occasional Causes of a Cholerick Cholick, are the same with those of a Looseness. The Corruption and Acrimony of Food in the Stomach, the assumption of Sharp, Costick
Medicines, such as Antimony, Arsenick, Mer∣cury, &c.

If the Excrements are Livid, Faetid, Black, or Corrosive; if it accompany Malignant Fe∣vers, especially in the Beginning, and if the Stomach is much disordered, it generally proves fatal. 'Tis an Acute Disease, and quickly finishes its Course. It observes a Tertian Period in its Exasperations, and fre∣quently relapses after an apparent Cure.

Symptoms.The Signs preceding this Disease, are, frequent and plentiful Evacuations of Cho∣lerick, sharp and corrupted Humours, up∣ward and downward, swelling with Wind, Thirst, and gnawing Pains in the Stomach and Guts: A Loathing, which a little ap∣peas'd with cold Drink, which is soon after cast up. The Pulse high and unequal, Sweating, with Convulsion of the extreme Parts and Swooning, are dangerous Symptoms. 'Tis easily discover'd whether the Disease came by some violent Medicine, Poison, or of∣fensive Dyet.

The Internal Causes are known by the Quality of the Humours that are ejected. If there be continual Loathing and Gnawing, the Disease is in the Stomach. If a Malignant Fever is join'd, it is in the Veins. If it has its Original from some ill Diet, there is Hopes, that when the peccant Matter is cast out, the Disease will end. If its very vio∣lent, 'tis dangerous, for the greater the Con∣vulsions, Swoonings, and Coldness of the extream Parts are, the nearer Death is at Hand.

In the Beginning of the Cure, you ought to assist Evacuations with gentle, cooling, and cleansing Clysters, especially Milk Clysters,
with Venice Treacle, or Diascordium dissolved in them are always useful. It's proper to breathe a Vein, to cool the burnt and boiled Blood, but let it be done with Discretion, Twice or Thrice, if the Strength be not impaired by the First. Endeavour to qualify the sharpness of the Humours after this manner. Waters of Plantane, Purslane and Mint of each two Ounces: Syrup of Quinces, and dried Roses, of each one Ounce; Syrup of Vinegary, half an Ounce, mix them, and dissolve therein two Scruples of Theriack Andromachi, and six Drops of Oil of Vitriol: Give now and then a Spoonful. But if the Patient has some Ease, and if the Symptoms abate or disappear, take great care that they dont suddenly return, to your Amazement and the Destruction of the Patient, as it sometimes happens unforeseen in this Case. Therefore Nourish him and Strengthen his Stomach, says most of our Eminent Physicians, with a Restoring Opiate, compounded in or after this Method. Gelly of Harts-Horn made with Canary Wine, four Ounces, Conserve of Roses, Burrage, Bugloss and Clove Gilly-Flowers, of each one Ounce: Confectio Alkermes, half an Ounce, Citron Bark and Nutmegs, Candied, of each three Drams; Essence of Cloves, Mace, Nutmegs and Cinamon, of each three Drops, and with the Syrup of Clove Gilly-Flowers make On Opiate; of which must be taken the quantity of a Hazle Nut or more, Mornings and Even∣ings. Of all the Medicines used against Looseness, says a great Author, Opium is the chief, being a powerful controler of all tumultuous Motions and accordingly pre∣scribes Laudanum Opiatum, or Liquid Lau∣danum in large quanties, for the Cure of this and most other Diseases.

But for my part, tho' I won't pretend to censure the Practice of my Superiors, yet I think my self obliged to say, that I tamper not with Opiates, nor ever use Laudanum but on extraordinary occasions, being rather a Pallative than a Curative Medicine; and therefore in my Practice for the Cure of this or any other Disease I pretend to Cure, I only employ my own Experiencd Medicines, which by their own native vertue subdue Diseases by their amicable correspondence with Nature, and by assisting her in all her Operations and endeavours, to support her self, and exterminate those noxious Invaders, that disturb her desired Peace and tranquility. And that I have such efficacious Remedies for the Cure of this Disease, if timely con∣sulted, will appear by the following Ex∣amples.

my Remedies justice, and that others might reap Benefit by the same means, he has or∣derd me to send any Person to receive Sa∣tisfaction from his own Relation, which I am always ready to do.

Mr. John Shadwel, near the Sign of the Three Mariners, in the Parish of St. Thomas Wapping, Mate of a Merchant Man, having been a long Voyage, and feeding much up∣on Meat that had been long salted, at his comming on shore, was violently taken with frequent vomiting and Purging, attended with great Weakness of Body, a chilness in the out∣ward Parts and unexpressible Pain. He con∣sulted two Physicians, took the Medicines they jointly prescribed, but those Gentlemen being frighted at the appearance of a slight convulsive Motion in the Patients Face and Eyes, gave him over as Incurable: Whereupon I was sent for, and by the Blessing of God upon one single Medicine, he had Ease in less than Ten Minutes time, and continuing the same Medicine but four Days together, was perfectly Recovered, and so remains to this Day.

The Dy∣sentery or Bloody Flux.A Dysentery, which the Greeks name , properly so called, proceeds from the Ulceration of the Intestines, but is commonly taken for every Bloody Flux: The Latins call it Tormina from the excessive Pain the Patient endures. This Disease which is voiding Blood and purulent Matter with tormenting Pain, is distinguishd from the Painless Evacuation of Thin, Watery Blood from the internal Hemerroid Veinsm, called by the Ancients a Flux of the Liver,
and likewise from the Natural discharge of Blood independent of the Guts, causd by its redundancy in the Body, as after Ampu∣tation, suppression of the Menses, &c. or by its Acrimony opening the Vessels, or the Obstruction of the Bowels hindering its re∣gular Circulation. Agreeable hereunto, Galen mentions four kind of Fluxes, all which he calls Dysenteries. The first is when any usual Evacuation of Blood, as the Hemer∣roids, or at the Nostrils is impeded. Secondly, When Watery Blood is voided, occasion'd by the Weakness of the Liver. The Third is, Blood mix'd with melancholly and burnt by reason of its being detaind in the Liver and Spleen is evacuated and shines. The Fourth and last, and that I am now treating of, is, when Blood and Excrements are mix'd toge∣ther, and sometimes also purulent Matter accompanies it, to the Patient's intolerable Pain.

Symptoms of a Dy∣sentery.The Diagnostick Signs of the Bloody-Flux, are, that the Sick Person is seized with un∣sufferable griping Pains in the Guts followed by frequent Stools, first of Whitish Matter, and afterwards of Blood and Slime mix'd to∣gether. Watching, Thirsting, loathing Food, and sometimes attended by a Malignant Fever and all its dismal Symptoms. If the Small Guts are affected, the Pain is vehement, like the pricking of Pins, because they are of exquisite Sense: The Patient goes not to Stool presently after the Pain, and when he does, is grievously tortur'd, and the Guts and Bowels seem to fall down. If the Great Guts are affected, the Pain is not so sharp, and being seated toward the sides of the Belly, is quickly followed by Stools; the
Blood swims on the top, or is a little mixd with the Excrements, and you may judge of the Humour causing this Disease, by the Colour of the Excrements, Age and Tempera∣ment of the Patient and the Season of the Year.

There are Three degrees observable in a Dysemery. The Symptoms of the first are Bloody and Slimy Stools. In the Second, the Slime is a Sign of Excoriation and in the third of an Exulceration. When the Guts are Excoriated, 'tis either the Crust that co∣vers them, or part of their thick Tunicle, or at most the Caruncles, or inflamed Glandules of the Guts that is voided.

Progno∣stick Sym∣ptoms.A Dy∣sentery caus'd by black Choler is a dangerous Sign, if it be not Critical, because the Ulcer grows Cancerous; be sure there∣fore you make a right judgment between melancholly and congeal'd Blood. If loathing of Meat and a Fever accompany it, 'tis dangerous. If Pieces of Flesh be voided in it, 'tis Deadly. Much Watching, great Thirst, Black Bloody and Stinking Stool, without a mixture of Humours, Hiccough, Cholerick Vomitings, Pains in the Liver and Midriff, are generally deadly Signs. If Choler and sharp Diet is the Cause of this Disease, its easily cured; Salt Phlegm is worse, because sticks longer in the Guts. If the because it sticks longer in the Guts. If the Bloody Flux happens to one troubled with a diseased Spleen, or the Gout, its good, in the Opinion of Hippocrates, because the Matter is sent forth. But I rather take this for a Diarrhea than a Dysentery.

Causes of the Bloody Flux.The Internal Causes of this Disease are sharp and Ʋlcerating Humours. Yellow Green, and Black Choler; Salt Phlegm in the
Head created by Heat, or in the Belly by Putrefaction. which being brought to the Guts, and sticking close to them Ulcerates the Part. The sharp Acid that irritates the Guts, provokes them to Contraction, assem∣bles the Blood by vertue of its provocation, and corrodes the Orifices of the Blood Vessels. This may proceed from the corrupted Mat∣ter in the Guts. But the cause of a Malig∣nant, Epidemical, contagious Looseness, such as the Learned Sydenham discourses of, as hap∣pening in the Years, 1669, 70, 71, 72, is a corrupt volatile Acid, not lodg'd in the Guts, but immediately reigning in the Blood, per∣verting its Texture, opening the Vessels in∣serted into the Guts and provoking them to Convulsive Contractions; from whence is derived a Malignant Fever, Griping and Bloody Stools: So tho' the previous excoriations may take place in benign Dysenteries, there is no occasion for them in the contagious Ma∣lignant sort; it being a sufficient Cause of bloody Stools, that the Costick Ferment is a Mortal Enemy to the Intestines, like Arse∣nick, that perpetually thwarts and provokes them to Convulsions; upon which, says that excellent Author, they squeeze out their Blood together with their Nutritious Juice, that they are not then in a capacity to re∣ceive; and which is taken by some for the Mucus or Snot of the Guts, whereas the large quantities that are voided, sufficiently evince the contrary.

The External Causes, are all such things as procreate sharp and ill Humours, as Meats which soon putrify ill the Stomach, Fruits which are soon rotten, and all things un∣ripe: The Air thus qualified; the Winter
co'd and dry, and the Spring very Wet and full of South Winds, cause Dysenteries in Sum∣mer. Or if the Winter be Wet and full of South Winds, and a dry Spring, and the North Winds blow much; such a Season generally speaking produces Bloody Fluxes. Sometimes the Air is infected and produces a Conta∣gious and Epidemical Dysentery, which is so infectious, that the Excrements of the Sick being cast into a Bog-house, infect, all that sit over it. To which may be added, the taking of Mercury, Coloquintida, Antimony, Lead, the course Pouder of an Adamant, Worms, &c. which vellicate the Guts and heap up sharp Humours in them.

To Cure of the Bloody Flux.From what has been already said, you may rationally infer, that Indications for Cure of a Dysentery, are, to evacuate sharp Humours, asswage Pain, Cleanse, Consoli∣date and Dry the Ʋlcers, Purify the Blood, separate the preternatural Ferment and stop the Flux.

To discharge the Body of sharp Humours you must Purge every Second, Third or Fourth Day, according to the Patient's Age and Strength, and the Season of the Year. Rhubarb given in Pouder a Dram, a Dram and half, and two Drams is very usual; but because Pouders are apt to stick to the Guts and vex them, I better approve of it converted into a Potion, made of Liquoras, Raisms of the Sun, Tamarinds and yellow Myrabolans boiled in Bar∣ley-Water, to Three or Four Ounces; which Li∣quor being strained, infuse in it a Dram of Rhubarb sliced very thin; then add an Ounce of Syrup of Roses Solutive, and you have a very good Medicine to evacuate sharp Humours.

If the Dysentery is accompanied with a Fever and Inflamation of the Bowels, open a Vein, let the Patient Bleed in proportion to his Strength. Sometimes vomiting is pro∣fitable, to repel the Humours, which fall from the Stomach to the Intestines, and there∣fore not to be omitted, especially if the Pa∣tient is inclined to Vomit, for then Nature dictates the right way, and ought to be im∣mitated, in disburdening a foul Stomach. Afterward you ought to give asswaging, mild and cleansing Clysters, and succeed them with Astringent Clysters.

If the Ʋlcerss stand in need of cleansing, add Centaury and Wormwood to the former De∣coction, and to the strained Liquor add Tur∣pentine dissolvd in the Yolk of an Egg, and the Chymical Oil of Wax, of each one Dram. When there is more need of Binding and Gluti∣nating Medicines, give Emplastick Clysters, to cover the internal Superfices of the Guts, and preserve those Parts from the Gnawing of the Matter.

To cleanse, give Goats Milk; to glutinate Cows Milk Chalybeated, which is proper to consolidate and heal, to which you may add the Juice of Plantan, Syrup of Comfrey, Sugar of Roses, Troches of Amber, and Rhasis's white Troches. Let the Sick eat Rice boiled in Cha∣lybiated Milk, or the Mucilage of Gum, Traga∣canth and Arabick, drawn with Rose or Plantan Water, the quantity of half a Dram in his Broath. To purify the Blood and separate the pre∣ternatural Ferment, Goddards Drops are often successful. And to compleat the Cure, the Body being throughly cleansed you may use Astringent Decoctions and Narcoticks to stop the Flux.

And if this Course and these Medicines are ineffectual, as sometimes to the Patient's disappointment and extravagant Charge, they have been too often found; let the Sick try my Medicines, which have never yet failed to cure the Bloody Flux, in nu∣merous Instances, of which I only give you Two Examples.

Mr. Alexander Carter, Taylor, dwelling in Swan-Yard, over against Somerset-House in the Strand, was sorrowfully afflicted with the Bloody-Flux above two Years together, with∣out any Intermission, insomuch that he had almost ruin'd himself in going from one Do∣ctor to another, and yet was still rather worse than any thing better, till he came to me and made use of my Remedies, which cured him in a few Days, and now continues in as good Health, as ever he enjoyed in his Life. To the truth whereof he is ready to make Oath, if desired.

Mr. Thomas Chiffinch, Carpenter, Aged Sixty odd Years, was Seven Years grieved with the Bloody Flux at certain Times; but the last Three Years had it constantly, and in so violent a manner as threatned him with inevitable Death, in the Opinion of all his Friends and Acquaintance; for he could find no Relief in all the means he used: But applying himself to me, and taking my Medicines, was cured in a short time, and at a small Charge; the truth of which im∣mediate Cure, will be attested to any Per∣son, that pleases to enquire either of Mr Clark, or the Patient himself, at Duglas's-Coffee House in St. Martin's Lane, Westminster.

Having now, I presume, said enough a∣bout the Cure of the Cholick in all its dif∣ferent kinds, and the other Diseases that generally accompany it, sufficient for the In∣struction of the Industrious and Ingenious, and too much for the Envious Idle and Ignorant, I should have concluded this Treatise, but because I resolve to publish several other Discourses on other Diseases, and that many People who have met with repeated Dis∣appointments in following other Mens Reme∣dies, before my Books now under Hand can be Publish'd; for their sakes as well as my own, I shall briefly shew, in a few Examples, in what other Diseases as well as the Cho∣lick, my Medicines have been wonderfully successful, and also that the over curious or suspicious may receive entire Satisfaction, by enquiring of the Persons I have taken leave to Name, and the Places where they dwell, in the following brief Catalogue, which I shall begin with the Head-Ach.

Head-Ach and Ver∣tigo. William Fletcher, of Engfield, in the Country of Middlesex, White-Smith, being grie∣vously afflicted with the Megrim, Gid∣diness and Swimming Pains in the Head, so that oftentimes he was in danger of falling down as he Work'd or Walk'd, which con∣tinued upon him for the long space of Six Years, and using divers Medicines for his Cure, but without Success; he applied to me, and I in letting him Blood in the inside of one of his Nostrils, and giving him a Medicine, he found immediate Relief, without any Pain or Trouble for above a Year; but afterwards finding a
Pain and Giddiness, on the other side of his Head, and I letting him Blood in the Nostril of that side, he was perfectly Cured of that Vexatious and Troublesome Disease.

Head Ach.Mr. Samual Haines, Broad-Silk-Weaver, dwelling in Fashon-street, in Spittle-Fields, London; was for the long space of Twelve or Thirteen Years, violently afflicted with the Head-Ach, and tho' he industriously sought Relief from other Hands, could find none, till he made use of my Remedies, and by them, the Almighty's Blessing in∣terposing, was thoroughly cured.

Edward Harrison, Leather Dresser, living with Sir Isaack Shard, Knight, in Horse-lye-Down, near Southwark, was sorely afflicted with the Head-Ach at certain times, which return'd very often, and continued to his great Chief in this manner Six whole Years successively, of which he could find no Cure, tho' he used variety of Medicines from no mean Professors of Physick; but at last ap∣plying himself to me, was perfectly cured.

Margaret Thomas, Servant to the late Mrs. Jux, who was her Majesty's Strower, and did then dwell in Little Scotland-Yard, ad∣joining to White-Hall, was grievously troubled with the Head-Ach for the space of Two Years, and with other Female Distempers much longer, with which she will acquaint any of her own Sex, that think-fit to en∣quire of her; but after the use of not a few Medicines prescribed by other Practitioners
in Physick, without effect; she was reco∣vered from all her Diseases by following my Advice, and the use of my Medicines, and continues in perfect Health to the pre∣sent time.

William Watson, late Servant to Mr. Welch,Vertigo. a Shoe-Maker, in Chancery Lane, London; was much troubled with a Vertigo, or Gid∣diness of the Head, between Five and Six Years, and sometimes so violently, that some thought it would terminate in a Ap∣poplexy or Epilepsy, of which Disease he could find no Cure, till he applied himself to me, and by God's Blessing, and giving him Ex∣perienc'd proper Remedies, he was restored to Health.

Moses Grant, late Servant to Mr. London, Perruke-Maker, in Channel Rowe, Westminster, was Fourteen Years troubled with the Head-Ach, and Four Years last past, was af∣flicted with it in so grievous a manner and with such intolerable Pain, without one Days intermission; and making use of divers Me∣dicines without Relief, he came to me, and I effectually cured him by giving him my Medicines in Six or Eight times, and he has continued well for a Year last past, as he assures me, excepting twice that he was slightly visited with it, by too hard Drink∣ing, which soon went off again, without the use of any means.

A Child of Mr. John Evans's, Frame-Work-Knitter, in Hand-Alley, in Bishops-Gate-street, was so grievously afflicted with sore-Eyes, occasion'd by a Defluction of
Hot Rheum on those tender Parts which con∣tinuing with great severity above a Quarter of a Year, 'twas the general Opinion she would be Blind; but her Father addressing himself to me, I perfectly cured his Childs Sore Eyes, and took away the Cause in Three or Four Days time, and left her as well as ever she was in her Life.

The WormsMr. Robert Guinn, at the Sign of the Two Brewers, in White Lyon Yard, near Norton-Falgate, in the Parish of Stepney; for some Years past was so abundantly Pester'd with Worms, that sometimes they drop'd out of his Body as he went along the Streets, and at other times crept from him when he was in Bed. He was also afflicted with an Excessive Ravenous Appetite, and yet tho' he Eat as much as would have sufficed Six or Eight Persons, he received no Nourishment by his Food, but fell away, and was so wasted in his Flesh, that he was little else than Skin and Bones. He had long sought Relief from many, and variety of means, but all in vain, till he came to me, and through Mercy I cured him of all these complicated and uncommon Distempers, in about a Fort∣nights time; and has continued in a good state of Health ever since.

The Son of Mr. John Carter, in George-Alley, in Coleman-street, London, who was a∣bout Two Years of Age, and terribly af∣flicted with Worms, and gnawing griping Pains, by taking my Remedies, voided above a Pint of Worms, was freed from his Pains, and has continued well ever since.
I could give you may other instances of Persons of both Sexes, Young and Old, but I reserve them for a particular Treatise of the Worms, that will immediately follow the publication of this Book.

Rheuma∣tism and Gout.A Gentleman of considerable Quality, Lame with a Rheumatism and the Gout to such a degree, that he dreaded the utter loss of the use of his Limbs; but applying himself to me, I cured him of his Rheumatism, eas'd his Arthritick Pains, and so restor'd the use of his Limbs, that he is capable of attending his own Affairs: And tho' he will not allow his Name to be Printed, yet I have his leave to send any Person to him, who will confirm the Truth of what is here but privately di∣vulg'd. To Name more Persons whom I have cured of the Rheumatism, is wholly needless, since the Weekly Papers have from time to time, publish'd to many. And tho'. I don't pretend to mke a perfect Cure of the Gout, yet I hope I may be allowed to speak truth, and say, That my Medicines never fail to give speedy Ease in the most violent Pains attending that Disease.

The Stone & Gravel.Mr. William Cordwell, Frame-Work-Knitter, at the Sign of the Black-Boy, in Wheeler's-street, Spittle-Fields, being violently afflicted with Suppression of Ʋrine, occasion'd by the Stone, Gravel, and a concommitant Cholick, which had continued at certain Times for Three Years last past, and since Christmas last in a more severe manner than ever; applied him∣self to me, and by the use of my Remedies aforenamed, voided several Stones and ob∣tain'd a perfect Cure: And having paid me
for my Medicines to my own content, de∣sired also, that his Cure might be publish'd, that others labouring under the same Di∣stemper, might receive Benefit by the same Hand and Means.

Francis-Wilks,Fevers. dwelling near the Sign of the Black-Horse, in Blackman-street, hard by St. George's-Church, in Southwark, was seize Five Months with a Tertian Ague, and having taken great quantities of Jesuit's Powder, or Peruvian Bark, and an incredible number of other Medicines, to no purpose; insomuch that he seem'd to be on the Brink of the Grave, and his Circumstances being but in∣different, I offer'd him his Cure Gratis, which I perform'd with great Expedition, and so effectually, that after the first Dose of Physick I gave him, his Fit return'd no more, and the Patient enjoys his Health to this Day.

The great number of Patients I have cured of Fevers, under all Denominations, whether attended or unaccompanied with a Cold shaking Fit, which are vulgarly call'd Agues, will excuse me from giving more Examples in this Disease, because my Medicines, are so well known to give relief in Fevers, that to commend them by Testimonies in un∣cessary waste of time, since they recommend themselves by their Innate Vertue; not be∣cause they are Hot, not because they are Cold, not because they Cut and attenuate; but because they have the peculiar vertue, to ex∣tinguish the hot fermenting Alkali, which is the Occasional, Internal and Continent cause of Fevers, and that they may effect what they are design'd for, I vary them as I find Oc∣casion;
because, vix ulla perpetua Ars Medici∣nalis recepit, scarce any of the Precepts of the Art of Physick are perpetual.

Coughs and Consum∣ptions.Mr. Thomas Adin, Weaver, dwelling in King's-Head-Yard, in Shore-Ditch, was long afflicted with a Consumptive Cough, attended with all the dismal Symptoms of approaching Death; but by the blessing of God, the Me∣dicines I directed him to take, perfectly re∣covered him.

Spitting Blood. Mary, Wife of Mr. Richard Darling Barber, formerly dwelt in Burchen-Lane, near Lum∣bard street, London, was in Three Years time last past, twice cured by Medicines of a vio∣lent Cholick and Spitting Blood, and the last Spring was seized with a Hectick Fever, and all the dreadful Symptoms of an approach∣ing Tabes or Consumption, and was given over for a Dying Woman by all her Friends and Relations; but by Heaven Blessing the Me∣dicines she took of me, she was restored to her former Health, as will be attested by more than Twenty Eye-Witnesses of her un∣expected Cure, as well as by the Patient her self.

The French Disease.In the next place I could give many Ex∣amples of Persons I have cured of both Sexes, of Gonorheas and the French Pox; but because to give Examples in such Cases, would be a horrid breach of good Manners; I shall only recommend my Medicines as Safe and Certain in the Cure, and my self for perfect Silence.

The Stone.The last Disease of which I shall give any Examples in this Book is the Stone, and shall begin in the well known Case of Mr. Richard Hurford, at the Sign of the New England Arms, near Ratliff-Cross, who was Twelve Years afflicted with the Stone, but lately in a most violent manner, and having taken abundance of Medicines in hopes of Ease, but all in vain, I gave him my own Medi∣cines experimentally adapted to the Cure of that Disease in his Case, which brought a∣way an incredible number of Stones, and some of them as large as were capable of passing through the Ʋreters and can scarce be credited by any, but those that have seen and handled them.

Mary, the Wife of Mr. Richard Pomfret, dwelling in Little Carter Lane, near the Swan Ale House, was afflicted with the Stone and Gravel to that degree, that upon any agi∣tation of the Body she made Bloody Ʋrine, and after she had had the Advice of several Doctors of Physick, but without success; the first Remedy I gave her, put a stop to her Bloody Ʋrine, and brought away a prodigious Quantity of Gravel, by which means she was Cured at a small Charge, and in a very short time.

Having thus plainly proved to the meanest Capacity, the efficacy of my Remedies the Sincerity of my Practice, and the Truth of the Examples of Persons cured, insomuch that they that are not blinded by partiality or by∣ass'd by Interest, must be Masters of a great deal of Sophistry, that will pretend to deny, contradict or oppose them. I should now put an end to this brief Discourse.

But having a little Paper to spare I shall employ it, in accommodating the Reader with the Vertues and Ʋse of a bitter Medi∣cament, which I invented, and call Tinctura Stomachicalis major, or the greater Stomachical Tincture.

Which is a Composition of all the Noblest Bitter Aromatick and Stomachical Specificks in the whole Materia Medica, and perfectly answers all Intentions accordingly. It enlivens and sharpens a languid Appetite, expels Viscous Humours; assists Fermentation and helps Di∣gestion; Fortifies the Stomach and prevents Nauseating and Loathing. It is Carminative, a great expeller of Wind out of the Stomach and Bowels; and as all bitter things are Me∣dicinal against Worms, so this Tincture has an excellent faculty that way. If any Person has the misfortune to drink bad Wine, or to drink to excess; if he mingles some Drops of this Tincture in his Wine, it will rectify all Disorders occasion'd by hard Drinking, and prevent next Mornings Head-Achs, loathsome Vomitings, and menacing Surfeits, the usual Attendants on Nocturnal Debauches. It's a good Remedy for Persons newly deliver'd from a Fever, or any Chronical Distemper, be∣cause it strengthens the Crasis, or convenient mixture of Qualities. It's proper for Ma∣riners to carry with them to Sea, and for those that Travel by Land, because it prevents ill accidents occasion'd by Ill or Scanty Diet, change of Air, and Epidemical Infections. It far excels all other bitter Medicaments; it never offends the Eyes, or causes breakings out on the Skin, as generally all other Bitters do. It will keep good many Years, and may be taken in Wine, Ale, Tea, or Spring-Water,
from Thirty Drops to a Hundred, in the Morning, and at Four or Five of the Clock in the Afternoon, when People find occasion for it, either to cure Diseases, prevent them, or confirm one in a State of good Health, in which I have found my Tincture successful in many Years Practice; being as pleasant a Bitter as Art can contrive. One Ounce of Mine will make Three Ounces of any other Bitter, that is commonly exposed to Sale. And that the Poor may receive Benefit by it, I will Sell it to such as really are so, for Two Shillings the Ounce, and Twelve Pence the Half Ounce.

T u of th Cpta∣ Sn.For the Cure of the Head-Ach, Deafness, Vertigo or Giddiness, and the Cure of an Old and Inveterate Cough, I have also a Caephalik Snush, which snuffed up both No∣strils, Night and Morning, till the Nose runs plentifully, will produce the desired Effect; but when this and other Remedies fail, as the best sometimes do; I have ano∣ther way of curing the Head-Ach, and Ver∣tigo, by Phlebotomy, in the Part, and by a safe Method scarce known, or practis'd by any other Person.
